So you've got four workouts covering the whole body over a six day period. Having said that, you've got to be flexible. You've got to listen to your body if you need more days to recover. Then just extend that cycle into seven days or eight days or whatever you need. Extra negatives are a tool that you can use to increase the intensity. Basically, you've got three phases of strength. The weakest phase is a positive or the lifting of the weight. That's the weakest phase. Second phase of strength is a static. You're stronger on the static. And then the third phase is a negative. Unfortunately, a lot of people think in terms of just lifting weight. So for instance, a bench presser lifted the weight to the top. Or I'd job job done. Just drop it back down and do another one. They're missing half of the rip. And possibly the most important half of the rip. Because more muscle damage occurs on the negative than on the positive. And it's a damage to the muscle that the body repairs that then becomes muscle growth. So you're missing the most important part of the rip. If you don't emphasize that negative part. And even when you've gone to failure on the positive part of the exercise, your muscle hasn't gone to true failure because it's still strength-left and the negative. So that's why I advise sometimes doing additional negatives at the end of the set. If you've got a training partner, if you're on a machine and it's safe. For instance, you're doing bench press on a machine. You reach failure. You do a couple of force reps. Your positive strength is depleted. You fail. But you've still got something left in the negative. So you can get somebody to raise their weight to the top. And lower it slowly down for a couple of reps until you can't control it. That way, you've depleted every area of the rip. In the last season, a moderate amount of cardio. I think it's good for your cardiovascular conditioning. You need some decent amount of cardio to recover between your sets. So 25 or 30 minutes, three times a week, moderate cardio. I think it's good for some condition. It's also good for recovery when it works out. Because it helps your push-in blood-rounder system. I'll get rid of the waste products from the weight workouts. I prefer to do them on days that I'm not in the gym. Or if you schedule doesn't permit that. And you have to do it on the days you're weight trained. I would much prefer to do it away from the weight workout. I've known for years for my own feedback that if you do cardio after weight training, it kind of interferes with the recovery. The priority is the recovery from that workout and rebuilding your resources. So it's much better to do your cardio separately. And finally enough scientific studies are coming down and improving this. If you do cardio after weight, your strength gains are less than if you did weights on the run. You know, what happens if you've got an injury, if you've got a small tear in the muscle, your body will repair that, but it will repairs it with scar tissue. Scar tissue is not flexible, like normal muscle tissue. It's not elastic. So if you could think about an elastic band, if you snap to the elastic band, and then stuck it together with glue, with a lump of glue, it'll be fixed, but it'll no longer be elastic. And there's a good chance that that lump of glue at some point is going to snap again. So if you go to the injury, I think deep tissue massage is the best thing to do. Larry Scott, Harold Pool, and Earl Manard. Harold Pool still the youngest competitor ever at the Mr. Olympia 21 years old. The interesting thing to me, Dave, and a lot of people don't really know this story is how the Olympia came about. It came about in a bar. Joe Weater was actually sitting with Larry Scott. And Larry Scott was the poster child for bodybuilding, and Joe did not want to lose him, and Larry was telling him, it's really nothing for me to do anymore in this industry because I've already won all the big titles. So he got the brainstormed, let's do a professional contest for money that will let the best of the best be decided. Larry Scott liked the idea. And when he asked him, well, what would you call it? He looked down at his beer bottle, which was Olympia Beer and said, let's call it the Olympia. And here we are. We also had a shake things into perspective for just how rich this competition is and how long it's been around. The first Mr. Olympia, the one that you were talking about for $1,000, took place two years before the first Super Bowl ever happened. I mean, that's something. It's been around for that long. I'll be straining my neck and I'll feel it in my neck. Keep in my chin tucked and my placement is here for the bench. The second thing that people might get wrong is they have their feet too far out. Like this, you're going to feel that a lot more in the hamstrings or they have their feet too far underneath and you might feel this in the quads. So, what you want to do is keep the heels directly underneath the knees, the perfect particular to the ground. Your hands are perfect to the ground so when you come up, you have this close to a 90 degree angle in your knee. So, the third and most important is incorporating the posterior pelvic tilt to engage the glue to go through the movement. So, I'm going to stand up and show you guys how to do that. Incorporating the posterior pelvic tilt to her and the hipthro sexercise is beneficial for building the glutes because it optimizes the activation of the glue to your muscles. When you tell your pelvis posteriorly, you create a deeper stretch in the glue muscles at the bottom of the movement and ensure that you fully engage throughout the entire range of motion. This increased activation results in greater muscle recruitment and ultimately leads to more effective glute development and strength gains. Comment below if you found these tips helpful. Top 3 things you want to consider before doing cardio. Number 1. Identify purpose for your cardio. Are you doing it for weight loss? Are you training for a special event? Or are you looking to improve your overall cardio basketball endurance? When the destination is cleared, the directions will appear. No the reasons for starting cardio, so you can start cardio the right way. Number 2. Now that we've identified the goal, let's curate the plan. So start where you're at, not where you want to be. Meaning if all you can do is walk, just walk. None of us came out running. None of us came out even crawling. It took most of us two years to even take one step. So regardless of the destination, take your time and getting there. Number 3. Decide what metric you're going to use. Whether it's distance, time, or heart rate slash intensity. What gets measured gets managed. It's really easy to run three miles when you're feeling good that day. But if you set that as your standard and you try to do it or that you don't feel good, not only are you going to fail, but your motivation is going to fail with it. But if you have in place measure miss for what you're going to do and how you're going to do it, you set yourself to be a success every time you achieve it. And when you start with one mile every day, small, measurable, achievable. We're all in wasn't built in a day. It was built with the plan. Now go make yours. Let's work.

Bigger shoulders can make your waist look smaller, giving you the appearance of a bigger, broader, more powerful upper body. Not to mention, boosting self confidence, feeling more attractive, but here's where a lot of guys go wrong. Number one is neglecting the rear delts. Many guys will look in the mirror and attempt to visualize the improvements in their physique by building on what they do see, which is usually the anterior and lateral portion of the delts, while completely neglecting what they don't see, which is the rear or posterior portion of the delts. If you want to give yourself the appearance of having bigger shoulders, you must train rear delts. This will make your shoulders look much smaller, especially from the side angle. Some of my favorite exercises for building the rear delts are cable rear delflies. Unilateral rear delts cable flies or any variation of a high row. Number two is improper exercise sequencing. Instead of placing lateral raises towards the end of your workout, please nimit the beginning while your shoulders are fresh. Sequencing your workouts by prioritizing the underdeveloped or weaker muscle groups towards the beginning of your workout can help improve muscular and balances. And don't worry, your overhead pressing performance won't be hindered as much as you think, being that the medial delts are not as engaged in pressing movements as much as the anterior delts. Number three is stop-ingol lifting. I see guys cheating themselves on shoulder exercises more than any other muscle group. Just because you can get the weight up doesn't mean it will make you grow. I can say with confidence, I lift half the weight of guys half my size and for a good reason. Pick a weight that you can control through a full range of motion and learn to make lightweight feel heavy. When it comes to stimulating a hypertrophic response, yes, you need mechanical tension, but it has its place and that's after good quality controlled reps. It's not one or the other. Comment below if you found these tips helpful or if you want to see similar videos covering other muscle groups. And as always, don't have all the gains to see yourself share this video with the friend and enjoy the pop.

Alrighty guys, so here are four of the most common mistakes I see made in the gym when it comes to the cable lap pull down. So number one is going to be swinging our bodies back and forth on the machine. Using momentum to pull the weight. Remember we always want to be in control of the weight. We don't want the weight to be in control of us. Number two is going to be having an uneven grip on the bar as you perform the exercise. It's very easy to favor our dominant side. So remember to set up an even grip to avoid creating in balances. Number three is leaning too far back. This turns our lap pull downs into a rear-delt row, which for this exercise we don't want. And the fourth and final mistake I see is going beyond the appropriate range of motion. Pulling the bar all the way down to our belly button is an indicator that the weight is too light and you're not using the desired muscle group to move the weight. So now that we've discussed how not to do your lap pull down, let's have a look and see how we should be performing this exercise. First, we need to make sure that we have an even grip on the bar and our posture is in the correct upright position. Then, instead of pulling the weight with our hands, we want to think about driving our elbows down behind us, bringing the bar to our chest. Keeping control of the weight the whole time. Remember to focus on your mind to muscle connection, and if you ever lose this, light in the weight and double check your form and tech.

Alright, so the top five things I learned for running the Berlin marathon. Number one, make sure you have enough fuel and hydration. The biggest thing that I saw happen on race day was that a ton of people did not either pack enough gels or they had no sodium on them whatsoever. They had just water sessions that they were grabbing at every once in a while. I think the biggest thing that you can do is make sure that you had your hydration really mapped out nice and even. Big thing that I did was the night before I used a pre mix to get my carbohydrates in. And then throughout the race, I had six gels on me total. And every 35-ish minutes, I was making sure I was taking a gel. Each of those gels had about 40 grams of carbs in them. So I felt full the entire time. I didn't feel like I was getting depleted too fast. And I also felt that my hydration levels were great because I made sure to stop at every single water station. Number two, water station etiquette. Now this was something that was a little different in Berlin than probably other races. The water was only on the right side of the road in Berlin. And on top of that, the water stations use plastic cups instead of paper cups. It was plastic cups. So normally you can crumple something and throw it away. When this, it was a plastic cup. So you would try and break it and then throw it down. And it's something with triple brick because it doesn't break down as easily. So make sure to have great etiquette when you were going through those water sessions it really does help everybody else around you. Number three, make sure that you are fueling, properly leading into race week. The biggest thing that I knew a lot of people also did was they really laid the night before. And they just had this really heavy summer getting into race day. I was eating pasta all the way up into the day before the race. My last meal was at 2 p.m. 3 p.m. at the day before the race. And then I was making sure that I was getting enough hydration in throughout the entire night. So I made sure to get in my pre-pack of carbs, as well as my sugar, my glycusamine levels. I wanted to make sure that they were in a good place heading into race day so that I wasn't depleting as I was running and then from that, being able to put in any kind of impact or pain on my body. So very big thing to know, make sure your food plan heading into race day is as effective as possible. Little tip that I can say is the morning of I woke up my race, call time was at 9.15 a.m. I was up at six getting some carbohydrates into my stomach already. So I went through about three to four of these little caramel and honey waffles. I also had a pre-mix pack of carbohydrates. And then I had a banana and I was just drinking as many liquids as I can get in, leaning up into me heading out for the start line. Number four, make sure to use the bathroom before the race if you can. The amount of people who I talked to at the finish line were like, I wish I used the bathroom before the race and they didn't and then they had to stop on the side of the road and go to the bathroom. Like if you can use the bathroom before the race, do so I promise you would help you out. And number five, running in traffic. So not traffic is in the sense of cars, but traffic is in the load and volume of people in the race. There was 50,000 plus people riding the Berlin marathon. I went out inside the first wave of people with groups ABC and D and it was crammed. And the biggest thing I saw happen was running at a kit was kind of all over the place. The hard thing with an international race is also a language barrier. So I was really mindful to be using hand signals. As I went down to the right, I used a small little finger touch to the right. I was passing something on the left. I let them know I was passing on their left. Those things really become helpful in the race because when you have so many people around you, the smallest bump can trip somebody over and then lead into an argument. And then as I saw, lead into a couple little fights that were small and were de-escalated pretty quickly, but there was a bunch of people getting in people's faces. So be mindful of that. As you are on your run, just make sure to communicate with people around you. Make sure as I know it is a race, just be mindful that we're all here running at the same time. So that is a very, very easy tip to just take into your backpack. So those are my five tips in the Berlin marathon. I hope they help you in heading into your next marathon. So as you guys know, I got the New York City marathon on deck next. So I'll do the same video post in New York to give you some tips, tricks, and insights heading into that marathon as well.

For today's shoulder workout, we're going to be focusing on two things. So the aim of this workout is to pre-exost your shoulders before going to a machine press. The premise behind that is you use the free weights to completely pre-exost the shoulders, and then once your shoulders are shot, we're going to go to the machine, and we're going to be able to press your shoulders past the point of failure. We're keeping the pace up, like I always do, 45s to 60 seconds worth of rest, or long enough for your training partner to go. So first exercise for our shoulder workout today is going to be a bent over rear delts fly. For this exercise, we're going to perform four sets of around 15 reps. Is in my experience, the higher reps really allow you to put a lot of blood in there and stress the muscle properly. Much in the same way when you do your side ladders, the two-an-bring them out slightly in front of you, and then like I like to say dump them out, like their water bottles or something. You're going to want to do the same thing with this. You want to stay over the dumbbells. And I want to jerk, you're going to want to lift the weight up, and truly dump it out as you come up. What that's going to do is really isolate your rear delts, at the top of the rep, it should almost feel like someone's shoving an ice pick in there. So moving on from those bent over rear-thulls, we're going to go to cable side ladders. For this exercise, we're going to do four sets of 10-12 reps. You're going to notice I might do them a little differently than you've seen before. A, because I'm kind of hanging off the cable machine, and then B, I'm doing them behind my back. The reason I like to hang off the machine is it creates a point of stress, if you will, like kind of overloads the muscle at the bottom, until you get it past a certain point, and then it becomes a little easier again. As far as from why I do it behind my back, whenever you do cables in front of you, you have a propensity to pull it back like this, and it becomes more of a rear delt and back exercise, and it does a shoulder exercise. Doing it behind you really allows you to bring it slightly forward and truly dump it out with the cable, keeping tension on it the whole time. Moving on from those cable side ladders, we're going to go to a Smith Machine shoulder press. For this exercise, we're going to do four sets of 10 reps. The reason I'm using a Smith Machine or a Hammer Strength shoulder press, if you have one, is that by this time, after doing those rear delts and those side ladders, your shoulders are considerably tax, and your stabilizer muscles are starting to not be where they used to when they started the workout. What that means is you won't be able to stabilize free weight to the point where you're able to use your shoulders to the complete point of failure. So we utilize the machine to be able to drive to that point of failure because you're not having to stabilize anything. You're allowed to put 100% of the effort into moving the weight and feeling it in your shoulders. A couple things to keep in mind on this, is we're going to want to bring the weight all the way to your chin. It's going to be a little bit past parallel with your arm right here. It's going to be right to there. Do not take it to your chest. It's going to place a ton of stress on your front delts. You're rotate or cut up on your ac joint, but you definitely want to get a full range of motion to about your chin. Another thing to keep in mind is when you're pressing it, the second you get it past your forehead, try and stick your head through the window a little. What that's going to do is to activate your traps and really lock you in and allow your shoulder to completely contract the top of the rep. We're going to go to a reverse pectic for our rear delts. What guys think about growing a strong and muscular physique, the number one muscle group that they want to grow the most is their arms. Having bigger arms can completely change your guys' physique. When I first started working out, that was my goal, but I was going about it all wrong. I understand how frustrating it is to spend countless hours in the gym only to see minimum results. I've been there. It wasn't until I started implementing these five principles that I'm about to show you, which made my arms grow so fast that my friends were literally coming up to me and asking if I was on the sauce. Over the next 30 days, I want you to apply these training principles to help your arms grow bigger and faster. Let's get after it. Number one is prioritizing your heaviest lifts first, focusing on progressively overloading the muscle. You want to perform exercises that require the most energy in place the greatest amount of mechanical tension on the muscle towards the beginning of your workouts. Studies conducted by scientists at Harvard Medical School show that mechanical tension, which refers to the amount of force produced in muscles, is the most important pathway to muscle hypertrophy. So for biceps, that would be any variation of a barbell curl, an easy bar curl, or a pre-tracurl, for triceps it would be any variation of dips, overhead triceps extensions, or skull crushers. Your goal over the next 30 days is to increase the amount of weight that you can lift for six to ten reps, focusing on progressively overloading the muscle. Progressive overload is a method of strength training that gradually increases the intensity or difficulty of workouts over time. This is an important principle when it comes to muscle hypertrophy and building strength. Let's say for example, on week one, I'm able to perform a 90 pound easy bar curl until failure for three sets of eight reps. The following week I'm able to perform 90 ten reps and by week three I'm able to perform 10 to 12. I would increase the weight gradually five to ten pounds until it was difficult to perform eight reps to failure, continuing this cycle over time until I reach my goal. Number two is increasing your training frequency. Your arms can handle a lot more volume than you think, and one day per week or simply sprinkling in a few exercises after hitting chest or back may not be enough to increase the demand to grow. That's why I recommend restructuring your workout program to have two designated arm days per week. I structure my workouts and a push pull split format to maximize my time in the gym and increase my overall intensity. For example, on day one I will do chest and back on day two, I'll train shoulders and legs and on day three I'll train biceps and triceps. I'll take one rest day in between and then repeat. This format is beneficial because it's an efficient way to target muscle groups, allows for optimal recovery in between sessions and promotes a more symmetrical and proportionate development of muscles throughout the body. Number three is supersetting your biceps and triceps exercises. Supersetting biceps with triceps, meaning you're performing them back to back with little to no rest, can offer several benefits for muscle hypertrophy. It increases blood flow and pump in the muscles. It's more time-efficient, it enhances fatigue and muscle stress, and it stimulates a greater metabolic response. This heightened metabolic response can promote the release of growth hormone and other factors that aid muscle repair and growth. Although supersets can be effective for hypertrophy, they can also be quite demanding. Ensure a proper form and consider the weight used in your overall fitness level to prevent overexertion or injury. Number four is incorporating drop sets. A drop set is a weightlifting technique where you perform an exercise to muscle failure that immediately reduce the weight and then continue the exercise without resting. This technique extends the set beyond the point where you would normally stop, allowing you to push your muscles to the limit and induce more muscle fatigue. The goal is to exhaust the muscles as much as possible to stimulate muscle growth and increase strength. It increases the time-eutitension which causes greater muscle fiber recruitment and metabolic stress, both of which contribute to hypertrophy. It's also an efficient way to use different muscle fibers. The heavier weight activates the more strength-oriented, high threshold fibers, while the lighter weight as fatigue sets in engages the more endurance-based muscle fibers. This type of engagement can lead to greater overall muscle development. Although incorporating drop sets into your workout can have many benefits over using this technique could potentially lead to overtraining and increased risk of injury. Rotate and vary your training methods to prevent platos and allow for adequate recovery between intense workouts. Number five, the most important and most commonly overlooked factor when building any muscle group is your diet. If you're serious about putting on muscle, you need to be in a calorie surplus. This means you're consuming more calories than you're burning. Now, there's a right way and a wrong way to do this and a lot of guys get this wrong. We've all heard the freeze, you need to eat big to get big. Well, a lot of guys in turpentis is a green light to eat, whatever they want as much as they want. Without any boundaries, you'll find yourself packing on more fat than muscle just in time for you to cut back down for the summer with little to no additional muscle to show for it. I recommend starting with a slight calorie surplus and letting your body adapt to the increasing calories. A surplus of two to 300 calories above maintenance is a good place to start. Of the three macronutrients that make up your diet, proteins, fats and carbs, you need to prioritize protein. A good recommendation is consuming anywhere from 0.7 to 1 gram of protein per pound of body weight. So, for example, if you weigh 185 pounds, you should be consuming 130 grams to 185 grams of protein daily. I used my fitness powder track what I eat daily to make sure I stay on track. If you find yourself consistently falling short of your daily protein goals, you might want to think about supplementation. Speaking of supplementation, one of the most beneficial supplements that you can take to increase your performance size and strength is creatine. When it comes to taking creatine, the benefits are clear. It helps you to build muscle faster and helps you get stronger faster and improves anaerobic endurance and improves muscle recovery. What makes it even better is it does all of these things naturally and safely. For all of your supplement needs, visit bodybuilding.com to help you get started on your fitness journey. Comment below if you found these tips helpful and as always, don't hoggle the gain see yourself. Share this video with a friend and enjoy the pop.

Here are five ways to make you work out more effective when you're short on time. Number one, you want to prioritize compound movements. These are exercises that require two or more major muscle groups or joints to perform the movement. Some examples include squats, deadlifts, bench presses, overhead presses, pullups, and rows. These exercises engage more muscles and burn more calories compared to isolation exercises, making them efficient for time-strap individuals. Number two, incorporate supersets into your workout. A superset is when you perform one exercise to the next with a little to no rest in between. There are two ways to utilize this method. You can perform two exercises sequentially that stress two opposing muscle groups. For example, performing a dumbbell chest press targeting the chest and immediately going into a dumbbell row targeting the back. Or you can perform two exercises sequentially that target the same muscle group. For example, performing rear-doubt cable flies then immediately going into cable lateral raises. Both methods have their place when designing an exercise program and can provide several benefits, such as increasing the blood flow and pump to the muscles. It's time-efficient, it enhances fatigue and muscle stress as well as increasing the metabolic stress placed on the body. This can promote the release of growth hormone and other factors that aid in muscle repair and growth. Number three is utilize circuit training. Circuit training is a combination of three more exercises targeting different muscle groups with a short and breast period. You can utilize this training method to not only increase muscle size and strength, but also cardiovascular endurance. A great example of this is performing a circuit that includes pushups, dumbbell rows, dumbbell squats and a variation of an absurice. You can add 20 to 30 seconds of rest in between exercises or complete one after the other in succession and then rest after the circuit is complete. You will then repeat this for a set number of rounds. This approach allows one muscle group time to recover while another is being worked keeping the heart rate elevated, maximizing both strength and cardiovascular benefits. Number four is you can shorten your rest periods. Reducing the rest intervals in between sets can keep the intensity of the workout high, leading to more calories burned and improving your cardiovascular fitness. Aim for rest periods of 30 seconds to a minute between sets to keep the momentum going. Keep in mind this method will make it more difficult to work with heavier loads because it is so taxing on the body. Number five is focusing on intensity, not duration. Instead of spending a lot of time at the gym, focus on making your workouts more intense. Increase the resistance, lift heavier weights or perform exercises with proper form and control to technical failure. By increasing the intensity you can achieve a more effective workout any shorter amount of time. You will also find that you will not have to perform as many sets per muscle group in order to see significant gains that's having to spend less time in the gym. Remember to listen to your body and choose exercises that are going to align with your level of fitness and your goals. As always don't high goal against yourself, share this video with the friends and enjoy the pop.

Hey guys, Hunter LeBraude here. Today I wanted to take you through some tips and tricks I've learned over the years for training your arms. Alright guys, let's get into our first exercise for biceps. It's going to be standing alternating dumbbell curls. Alright, so the first tip I have for you specifically for biceps is to internally and externally rotate your hand through the rep. What I mean by that is as you near the bottom of the rep, you're going to go from here down to here. You're going to allow it to rotate. What that's going to do is it's going to allow the long head of your bice to become fully stretched and extended at the bottom of the rep. Whenever you have to start curling from that fully stretched and elongated position, it's a much harder rep than it is when the muscles are already partially contracted. It allows for maximal recruitment of the muscle. So as we continue through the rep, that rotation will become up the external rotation will actually force both heads of the bicep to contract further than if you were to just curl it like that. The second tip I have for you today is one that you can apply to any bicep exercise that you're performing and that is to pull your shoulders back when you're performing your bicep motions. What that's going to do is it's going to take your front belt and your chest out of the equation. So whenever the rep start getting hard you're unable to go like this because your shoulders are going to be pulled back and all of the motion has to occur at the elbow joint. Whenever we're performing it, most people you see how my shoulders are over, we're curling, yeah it works. Whenever you pull your shoulders back, your bicep's are locked in, your elbows are locked in and you're able to get a much better contraction by doing this. So throughout the rep, whenever you keep your shoulders contracted, you're able to keep all of the stress on the bicep. The stiff involved use of a bench to change the point of attack on the bicep and allows for a truly isolated bicep motion. Now, let me show you what you can do with the bench to truly change the dynamic of the exercise. All of it is going to involve is taking the bench and one may be two holes down where to position where we lean back and we truly are with the shoulders back and the elbows back. But this does it places all the stress on the bicep. This variation of the bench curl, I like performing with a actual bicep curl instead of a hammer curl because you can truly isolate the bicep and get a better contraction by using this angle on the bench. What's important when you're doing it this way is to keep your shoulders back. To whatever you're at this angle like this, you have a propensity to come forward like this to try and curl it. That's not right. You're going to be using your chest and your front belt. You want to stay back with your scap you like contracted keeping your arms and elbows back in your elbows pin. Now that we've gone over the tips that I have the offer you for training your biceps, let's move on to the tips that I have to offer for training your triceps. So my first tip that I have for training triceps today is to not flare your elbows when performing the motions. What this does when you flare your elbows is it takes a lot of stress off of the tricep and places it into your elbow. Elbow joint and the various tendons that anchor your tricep and your forearm into there. Let me show you what it looks like when performing a school crusher. Whenever you flare your elbows like say like this, whenever you're coming back, I can already feel this and my elbows and my chest and my shoulders. All of the stress has been shifted from my triceps to the supporting muscles that I'm not even trying to train by doing this. Like I said before, we're truly isolating the motion so the only motion that's going to be happening is that the elbow joint, your humorous, the long bone and the top of your arm is not moving. So as previously mentioned, we're going to go just shy of lockout in an effort to keep constant tension on the muscle. So my next tip I have for you today is to internally rotate your hands or to turn them in as you perform the motion near the peak of the exercise. What that's going to do is it's going to allow for maximum activation and contraction of the whole tricep while placing an emphasis on the outer head of your tricep, which is an often neglected portion of your tricep. First, I'm going to illustrate this tip to you using a dumbbell kickback and then I'll show you what it looks like on a rope press down. All right guys, so to start, we're going to have the dumbbell here in a neutral position and then also we're going to have our arm like I previously said. We're going to want to keep the humorous as straight and isn't it's original position as possible. We're also going to want to freeze the shoulder joint in a lot for his little motion as possible having all of the motion come from the elbow joint. It looks like this. So as we extend, we're going to start with a neutral hand position and we're going to rotate back and tap truly allowing to isolate the tricep, especially the outer head. Now the left showing you how to really internally rotate your hand on a dumbbell kickback. Let me show you what it looks like on a tricep push down. Just like all of our other exercises, we're going to want to keep our humorous, really pin the shoulders back and as we move through the motion, we're going to want to internally rotate our hands. Keep our elbows pinned and truly externally rotate. There's a much, much heavier contraction and a lot more stress is placed on the actual tricep. You really can't apply this tip to absolutely anything that is an honor bar that's connected. Anything that you use a dumbbell for a cable for or a rope for anything, you can definitely use this tip and you'll definitely get a benefit from using it. Let's move on to my third and final tip for training triceps. This one has to do with close grip bench press. The problem I have with this exercise is people tend to keep their hands way too close. What this does is a places an extreme amount of stress on their wrists, be really places a lot of stress on the AC joint and your shoulder joints and see it takes a lot of the stress off of your triceps. What we're going to do is scoot your hands out just a little bit, you're still going to be close for me. It works out to be approximately my pointer fingers on the start of the knurling. We're going to get out here. We're going to keep our elbows tucked and you're going to keep all the stress on the tricep by doing so. So at the bottom of the rep, we're able to keep the elbows tucked, the stress on the tricep and we have a firm firm grasp on the bar and that an extreme angle on your wrists. Looks like this. So the first muscle that we're going to talk about here today is the diaphragm. A lot of people don't talk about the diaphragm, but it's a critical muscle as far as respiration goes. So what you're going to imagine here from the front inside of your rib cage, your diaphragm comes up all the way around, and then it actually attaches onto your lower back. So when you take a deep breath, your diaphragm comes down, and in a perfect world underneath you have your pelvis, and most importantly your pelvic floor. So that is there to help catch that breath, and it'll press your eyes that entire abdominal wall. So when you go to squat or deadlift or overhead press, you've got a really strong stable spine. Also in that deep layer, you have what's called your transverse abdominis. And it runs from what's called your linia alva, here on the front, which is just a fancy name for a big attachment point. So it comes all the way around and attaches onto your lower back. So those three muscles work in concert to help press your eyes, your deep or your inner core musculature. Next, we have that intermediate layer, which is essentially your internal oblique. So everybody's familiar with the external obliques on the outside, but if you could imagine external obliques run this way, your internal obliques run in this fashion. So you can imagine a muscle that runs from again, that linia alva, and comes down in across and attaches to your hip bone. From there, working your way even further outward, you've got your external obliques, runs from your ribcage, all the way down, connects to your pelvis and your hip. Most people think of an external oblique as a trunk flexor or a trunk rotator, while that's all fine and dandy. What we're going to show you guys here today is how important stability or control is through your core and your midsection. So these muscles are actually very important for posteriorly tilting the pelvis, or helping it roll back. A lot of people have a tendency to fall into what's called an anterior pelvic tilt. So the pelvis rolls forward, you get a lot of pressure on your back. So these muscles are important for pulling your pelvis back. Probably the major player that everybody wants to talk about, your rectus abdominis. So your rectus abdominis is this broad muscle that runs from your lower ribcage and your sternum or your breast bone, all the way down to the front of your pelvis, which is called your pubic synthesis. So once you guys have a basic idea of the anatomy there, you can start creating or constructing a better workout routine. First, you've got these really small muscles that span about two to four segments of your back or your spine called multifid eye. Now you're never going to see these muscles, but they're important because they help give your spine or your back feedback to your brain as to where it is in space, and they help you control little movements throughout your spine. Now on the wide grip pull downs, you really want to focus on keeping your back straight, and it's all about the form here. So I'm going to drop the weight and really just focus on the squeeze all the way down, and all the way up, letting my lats release at the top, and then pulling back down. Now during the straight arm pull downs, you really want to focus on keeping your arms straight, and just squeezing the whole time during that whole motion. During the low rope cable rope, this is all about just squeezing pumping as much blood into that muscle as possible. You're not doing heavy weight, so just go through it and just pump it out. At the end of this workout, you should really be feeling it. This is a great workout to build muscle, and at the same time burn a lot of calories. Let's talk about the core specifically. This one, I argue with myself about putting this one up front because everybody wants to know more about building a core. So core building 101, you know, Kira, it's no question that you're near the core queen. So I want again, same thing. I want to break it down to two different areas. There's the functional benefits of working core and gaining a stronger core. I always like to use that apple analogy. You bite out the middle of an apple. You can easily snap that apart. But then two, break down when everyone's always chasing visible ads. So one, let's talk about the functionality of the core and why it's important to have a strong core. Well, the core is the powerhouse of your body. Right. It's like playing in simple. It's, it is where movement stems from. It's where proper movement stems from or should. It is, you know, when we define the core, the easiest way to, without going into like an hour along dissertation of what your core, it's everything but your limbs essentially. So I think, you know, we throw the word core around so loosely as trainers and again, I think there's so many people out there who don't understand what that means. They think core, they just think gaps, like immediately. They're like, and you know, we toy with even just saying like, I hate just saying the word apps. Like it's very hard for me as a trainer to just say apps because I truly am always talking about your core when I'm talking about your apps. Right. Or when we're working your apps. So important to know that essentially, aside from your arms and your legs, the core includes everything up to the insertion of your lap muscle, right? All the way down through your, so your pelvic lumbto complex, that whole complex is part of your core. So training your core, one thing it is not is just doing crunches and just working your abs and time and attention of domino work. And it's not just even just doing a plank, right? So I think plank is what people think when you say, what's the best core exercise they immediately go plank. Not saying it is and it's a wonderful one. But I always say within, within training your core, I call it the core four movements and with a bonus there's five. I just like core four rhymes. But so it sounds really good, right? The first most important thing is learning how to truly engage and activate your core. And I think that's like the hardest part is really understanding not only the breath work that goes into training your core, but just the position of your pelvis in relation to your rib cage, in relation to your glutes all of it. And there's so much information out there about it. But in the easiest way to explain it is one of the moves in the core four, which is tabletop resistance. It's what I always start people with. So really simply if you lay on your back, right, you bring your knees over your hips and see of a 90 degree angle between your shin and your hamstring, feet are flexed. You want to feel in that position that your low back is anchored on the ground, right? So we often talk about doing a posterior pelvic tilt, like that posterior pelvic tilt. And the reason we say that is because the natural position for most people when they lay down is that they're going to have space between their low back and the floor, right? They have a little lord dosis, which is the curvature of the spine, the lumbar spine, right? So we have a natural lord dosis. And in order to alleviate that space, you have to do a slight tuck to the tailbone, right? That tuck often gets exaggerated. So what we're really meaning is like a neutral spine, right, is what we're looking for. And I think when you say, I think as a trainer, we say tuck and we tuck and draw in and we show that. And then people start to feel like they got to walk around, like, tuck, right? They're like, well, but wait, I'm like tucking. I'm screwed. It's horrible position where I live now. This is where I live. Like you see, and I'm always in this to kind of like, I don't want to just see you walk around town like this. Like this is not like life doesn't sit here, right? This is just giving you this is an exaggerated example to help you learn to engage your core. So I think it's important to remember that that, like, sometimes you'll hear trainers talk and just with a grain of salt, take it with a grain of salt that you want to tuck and draw in to the point where your low back is anchored on the ground, but not that horrible, like, over, you know, that nobody would want to see. Like it's horrible posture, because it creates a rounding of the shoulders as well. But when you're laying down, that slate tucked at the tailbone. And then you place your hands on your quads and you drive your quads into your hands at the same time you are pressing away. So you're creating massive resistance in your entire abdominal wall, right? By driving those quads toward you, pressing the quads away at the same time, low back is anchored down and your ribs are wrapped. And that's a confusing term to people sometimes. So when you say ribs are wrapped, all that means is that a rib flare. This is a rib flare where I'm standing and I'm like, chest out and I'm arching my back, right? But to wrap the ribs, you do that slate tuck and draw in and it's like knitting your ribs in. It's like going like this, right? And you hold that for 10 seconds and you just push and that's where you're really going to feel. That's the first step I always have people do for activated in their core for really feeling what's going on. And it takes time. It is like, it is not easy, you know, when someone says engage your core. Nine percent of people are like, I've annoyed over the means. Like, what is that? Like, so that's the best way I can describe it. Like, I feel like that gives you the best connection from there. So that's like the first core move that of the core for. Then dead bug. What you want to do is lock the elbows in high and tight bring it through that range of motion and the controlled fashion so you can maximize muscle fiber recruitment. Right at that peak contraction rotate the palm upwards towards the ceiling. Here we go. That's your basic kickback. Take it up a notch, turn the palm up and add that extra challenge and intensity. This is where the pain starts. By doing 21's on the preacher curl, you're increasing the muscle's time under tension. And what that is doing, you're forcing extra blood, extra volume, oxygen, nutrients, into that muscle and it's signaling the muscle to grow. All right, here we go tip number three. I'm going to go to that overhead kettlebell extension for the triceps. So why kettlebell over a dumbbell? It's a different tool kettlebell hangs below the palm of the hand. We're hitting that long head of the tricep. Big mistake here is you see people flaring out the elbows. You want to try to keep them as tight as possible and really control that movement for quality reps. So here we go with tip number four. I'm going to the in and out barbell bicep curl. So here we go grab your barbell, tight grip, but four to six inches apart, elbows tight to the body, bang out six to eight reps. So that inside grip is a great way to add width to the arm because you're hitting that break your radialis and that break your allus muscle that's often neglected. When you're done that inner grip, put that barbell down, switch to a wider grip, a little wider than shoulder width, keep the elbows tight, that's the key here, keep the elbows tight and curl that weight up and now I'm feeling that stretch shift to that inner bicep head, bang out six to eight. And that's your in and out bicep barbell curl. Tip number five is going to be the twenty ones on that lying skull crusher. So I'm going to use a bent barbell for this one. I'm taking that traditional body weight dip and I'm shifting all my weight to one side one tricep and then again shifting all my weight to the other side. And I want to start at the top. Lock my legs back. I want to be straight up and down. This is a tricep movement. If I was hitting chest I would hit a forward lean but for tricep straight up and down. So I want you to go dead center down to the bottom and shift all that weight over to the tricep on the right side. Again take that negative center at the bottom, upper arms parallel to the ground and then drive and shift all that weight over to that left tricep. Dead center shift. Tip number seven is going to be across the body with the hammer curl. So one arm at a time adds more focus to the exercise. Cross the body is going to hit that break you already Alice and that break the Alice muscle which is key because it's going to add width to your arm. So if you're used to just doing straight up dumbbell curls or barbell curls you're going to want to add across the body hammer curls to your repertoire to get more out of each arm section. One mistake I see is people are swinging. They're throwing that elbow up and forward. You're going to get that shoulder taken over and taking away the straps from the bicep. So let's keep the elbow tight to the body. Let's focus on form and technique. Tip number eight is my closed grip, bench press, that basic math builder for the overall tricep muscle. I'm going to be using a standard 45 pound bench bar. I'm going to lie back. Take a grip position with the hands about six to eight inches apart. I'm going to start right over the chest. Keep the elbows tight to the body. Drop them down to the ground. Keep them tight as I press up into that tricep muscle. As I'm pushing up, I'm driving my shoulders back into the bench to maximize that tricep involvement. I recommend that you do the closed grip bench press, tighten with your chest and shoulder day because it does hit the inner chest and it's a great compliment to that workout protocol. Alright guys, tip number nine I'm going to go under hand grip on your tricep press down. So glue the elbows in tight to the body. Again, under hand grip, squeeze out that rep, come up about chest level and then full extension of that elbow joint. What that under hand grip is going to do is target the medial head of the tricep. The exercise is a little bit tougher than your overhand press down so you need to cut down the weight a little bit. Tip number ten final tip for you, the Zottman curl. Literally anybody does this move and you should be doing it. Here's why you're going to hit the biceps on the way up, you're going to hit the break your radialis and the break the allus and you're going to hit that forearm on the way down. It's a complete bicep forearm exercise. The first thing you want to do for this exercise is grip the dumbbells tight to the body. So when you curl up, you're going to pause and when you go into that reverse grip, you have optimal positioning to hold onto the forearm and slowly lower in that reverse curl. You're going to supinate palm up, biceps, then you got palm down, break your radialis, break your allus and forearm on the way down. When a great movement and I know you're not doing it and you should be doing it so throw it into your arm workout. Take it up to that next level. You're going to want to check your ego on this one, drop the weight and get proper technique and quality reps in, make the most of this exercise. So those are my top 10 tips for arms. Hey guys, this is Brian Cassette. This is a hard arm workout. It's more of a muscle building workout and endurance at the same time because we're doing high reps, we're doing heavy weights, we're doing supersets. So we're just hitting it at all angles. The reason why built the supersets the way I did is because you don't have to go clear across the gym to do the superset. To use you done with one, go to the next one. It's also there to get you in and out of the gym as quickly as possible. For today's workout we're going to start off with a more amount. We're going to superset tricep pushups with closed hand chin ups. During these tricep pushups, I'm actually doing 20 reps on each side. Going from side to side with these tricep pushups. You're isolating your tricep even more on each side. It's kind of like doing an aided, one-handed pushup. So during my chin ups, reason why I don't bring all the way up to the top or lock it out at the bottom is I want to keep a constant flex on my bicep. At the end of this warm up, I'm almost feeling like, man, I'm already getting a good workout in, but at the same time, I'm just getting ready to go. For this superset we're going to start off with the dumbbell curls. You're going to do 16 total reps that's eight on each arm. They're going to move right on to the skull crushers. We're going to do anywhere from 12 to 15 reps. On both of my mucing the bench, so it just goes back and forth. It's really easy transition periods. So going into my seated dumbbell curls, I am going with a larger weight. I like pushing it as hard as I can, but I did choose a row or a rep level. For rest periods on these, I want you to go anywhere from 30 to 60 seconds, try not to exceed 90 seconds. You just sit there and put your headphones in a new concentrate. You think about that next set. What am I going to do? Am I going to push it even harder this time? It's a don't f*** with me mindset. So for this next working superset, we're starting off at the standing straight curls. We're doing anywhere from 10 to 15 reps on those, and then we've got cable tricep pushed downs. We're doing 15 to 20 reps. So for these standing straight curls, I call them straight curls because I've locked my elbows in, and I don't let them move it out or anything like that. But at the same time, I still let my body have a little bit of a sway in there. Say if I'm doing 15 reps on this one, if I'm down to 13 and 14, and I'm kind of struck one a little bit. I'm going to give it a little bit of a kick. The dirt needs cable tricep pushed down and I keep it swollen controlled. Reason being, I like feeling that contraction at the end. So it's like when I push it down, it's just really contracted at the end and bring it right back up slowly. Contract it at the end right back up slowly. After this working set, my biceps and triceps are on fire. These first two weighted supersets that I have in the middle. These are the hardest ones and I did it on purpose. You want the hardest ones you get it over with and then the last one you just exhausted out. So this is the last working superset in this entire workout. It's what we're doing, we're going to do tricep kick backs with the cable, doing 25 reps on each arm. That's 50 reps total. They were switching right over to the standing cable curls and we're doing 25 reps on that. You're going to be doing six sets of all of this. So that's six sets of 75 reps. That's a lot and that's a way to post exhaust your body. The reason why I put this at the end of the workout is this is my finisher. This is the grant for now. It's not going to be a killer, it's not going to be like those heavy ass dumbbell curls that I was doing but it is going to just finish out the pump in the end. While sitting at an exercise bench with back support, hold two dumbbells in front of you at chest level with palms facing your body and your elbows bent. Your arms should be next to your torso. The starting position should look similar to the contracted portion of a dumbbell curl. To perform the movement, exhale and raise the dumbbells upward while rotating the palms of your hands outward until they're facing forward. Continue lifting the dumbbells until your arms are extended straight above you. After a brief pause at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells to the starting position by rotating the palms of your hands toward you.

Today's workout is my insane, fat-tourcing workout. It's six exercises. You're going to do each exercise for 30 seconds followed by 15 seconds rest. Today's workout isn't just great for burning fat, but it's also great for anybody looking to get in better shape. Anybody from an athlete to the guy who's building muscle, this workout is great for all those things. The other thing that is important to note about the workout is we're not going for reps, we're going for time. So within the 30 seconds the goal is to do as many reps as possible and to improve that every single week. Paced of today's six exercises that we're going to be performing are the following. Standing medicine ball throws, medicine ball wall throw with a push up, shadow boxing, half burpees, five yards, shuttle drill, finishing it off with jump rope. So remember guys, this is a circuit so you're going to be completing this entire circuit three times at the end of each circuit. You're only resting 15 seconds and you're going right back into the circuit. This entire workout should take you around 15 minutes, which is great because you can get in the gym and out and get the job done. The weight of the ball that you're going to use for this exercise really depends on the person. It's a potential like to go lighter because we are going for 30 seconds and I want you to be as explosive as possible. So a heavier ball may fatigue you within the first 10 seconds, but that's kind of a personal preference. So probably the most important thing that you need to focus on with the medicine ball throws is keeping your core really really tight because that's what's actually going to allow you to perform the movement the way it's meant to be performed. The other important thing to note is that you can perform this exercise by standing in one place or by moving in a circle, which just adds another element of movement to the exercise. You want to be performing this exercise at 100%. But when you bring the ball overhead, that's when you really want to focus on tightening the core because that's going to actually allow you the ability to slam the ball on the ground really hard. The next exercise that we're doing is a medicine ball throw with push-ups. So probably the first thing that you need to figure out is spacing between yourself and the wall and test it out. When you perform this exercise, you're throwing the ball against the wall and as you're throwing, you're going to come back down and go into the push-up and as you're coming back up out of the push-up is when you're going to catch the ball coming off with a ground bouncing close to you. Do a couple of reps, balancing the ball onto the wall and getting the ball back to you in one bounce. The second thing is to make sure that you are coming all the way down in a full push-up position. This is a great exercise on the push-up side because it is myometric because you're explosively trying to get back up to grab that ball. On shadow boxing, you want to make sure that you have your feet staggered apart normally if you're right handed, you're going to lead with your left and if you're left-handed, the exact opposite. The point of this exercise is to really keep your core really engaged and to be throwing punches as hard as you can. You're going to feel this in your shoulders and it's going to start to really burn and I love this exercise because you are able to achieve shoulder definition without lifting heavy weights which gives your joints a nice break. The other thing that's really important to mention with shadow boxing is it is people's tendency to want to hold their breath when they're doing this, make sure that you're breathing during this exercise and during the entire workout. Half-perfect, you're obviously doing the second part of the burpee movement which is you're excluding the push-up. So you're going to come down on the ground when you bring your feet in underneath you, the most important thing to do is to really keep your core tight. Make sure that your hands are hitting the ground, you're right underneath your shoulder and you're just standing up as explosively as possible but you're never leaving the ground. So this is a great exercise for bringing your heart rate up, increasing leg definition and strength but we're not doing a high impact exercise which again gives your joints a nice break while elevating heart rate. So remember you only have 15 seconds rest and then you're right into the five yard shuttle drill. This is a drill that I used during majority of my sports career. It's a great drill for legs, you build strength, definition. The key is it's multi-directional so you really want to get in and out of those transitions as quickly as possible. That's what's going to really burn your legs out which is exactly what we're trying to do within these three seconds. So don't shortcut it, go as hard as you can for 30. The last exercise that we're going to perform is jump rope and everyone has a different skill level of jump rope. The most important thing is you're doing the exercise. Don't just throw the exercise away because you're not the best jump rope or in the world. Jump rope is a great exercise to master because it has an amazing cardiovascular benefits and you can do it anywhere as long as you have a jump rope. For this workout, you can integrate this into any program that you're doing. You can add it before a workout or after a workout or both. So today's workout is a lower body leg circuit. And the difference between this workout and most leg workouts is that you have minimal rest between sets. I love this style of training for legs because it will shock your body into change. So if your person that's used to doing a lot of stuff on the leg press and taking a minute and a half, this is a great workout to really shock your body into changing once again. Over time, if you continue to do this workout, you will see a massive increase in muscle definition in the legs. So the exercises of today's workout are kettlebell side squat, leg extension, reverse lunges, seated hamstring curl, bodyweight squat, and finishing off with a defensive slide drill. So for today's workout, each exercise is going to be 30 seconds, as your rest will be as you're transitioning from machine to machine or exercise to exercise. You're going to complete this circuit three times in this workout should not take you any more than 15 minutes. So on the kettlebell side squat, you want to make sure that your proper spinal alignment and that your knees are not coming out over your toes. So those are the two things that you really want to focus on during a exercise. If you don't have kettlebells available to you, don't worry. You can use a dumbbell. On the exercise, you want to select a weight that you're going to be able to perform for the entire 30 seconds. Once you get the weight, you're going to perform a squat and then on the weight up, you're going to side step. With this exercise, you're going to take three steps to the right and then come back and three steps to the left and just repeat that for 30 seconds. This is going to work the legs in a multi-directional way, whereas a lot of leg exercises only work front to back. So this exercise is great for definition on the lateral and medial parts of the legs, as well as for athletes, because athletes obviously need to move multi-directional. So moving without rest right into leg extensions, with leg extensions, the thing that you really want to focus on during this exercise is choosing a weight that is not too heavy. You want to be able to do it in a manner that is fast-paced, but you're not going to blow your knee out while you're doing it. So make sure it's something where by the end of the 30 seconds, you should feel uninsane amount of burn and that you're keeping the movement very, very smooth and not jerking the weight up and down, because that does place and completely unnecessary stress on the knee. So with the reverse lunges, you do not have to do this exercise with weight, but if you want to, you definitely can. The biggest thing with lunges, you really want to be aware of your knee placement. A lot of times I see people doing lunges in the gym and their knees come and weight out over their foot. So with this exercise, you're simply taking a step back, dropping down, performing the lunge, and then coming back up, going back to your starting position and doing the same thing on the other side. For the hamstring curls, kind of the same principles as the leg extension, you want to choose a weight that's challenging, but you're not going to be burn out after the first 10 reps. The second thing is, is you want to make sure that you're keeping your butt firmly planted on the seat, and you're not sliding all around. It's very important to make sure that you're preserving your spine and other areas that can get injured during the exercise. For the body weight squat, you can perform this exercise obviously using no weight. Same principles as the kettlebell side squat, you really want to pay attention to your spine alignment so you don't want to be bending forward and cheating the exercise. The other thing you want to be aware of is that knee placement, not coming out over your toe so that you're dropping straight back and placing the majority of your weight on the heel. That's how you're going to get the movement to really place stress upon the glutes and the hamstrings rather than your claws and your knees. Alternately, if you prefer to use a leg press for this movement, knock yourself out on that, you're going to want to go wide foot stance and again, same thing, don't come down below 90 degrees. With the defensive side, you want to get into the squat position and you want to transition again, explosively out of the turn. For these slides, you're going to be covering about five yards of distance. This exercise is specifically for side to side movement and it really brings in the beautiful lines of definition of the size of the legs, which is what everybody wants and gets you kind of away from getting locked into that front to back movement, which most leg machines offer. So again, you're going to go through each one of these six exercises for total of 30 seconds with no rest in between and you're going to perform the entire circuit of total of three times and this workout should take you around 15 minutes. This workout can be integrated into your training split by it being the mainstay leg workout for you for up to four weeks and then I recommend switching into something else or it can be an additional leg workout. So today's workout is an upper body circuit. The goal of this workout is to increase muscle definition of strength in the upper body. I love pairing circuits together because unlike pairing simply muscle groups, you're really placing a different type of stress on the body. So from going from a push up into a dip, similar muscle groups, but performing those exercises back to back in a circuit just stresses the body in a completely different way than it's normally used, which is why workouts like this work so effectively for fusting through platos and really making a difference in muscle definition and even the first week. 5 exercises for today's workout are push up to freak, half burpee pull up, body weight dip, bicep curl the overhead press, and a bow-soup plank push up. For today's workout, you're going to be performing 5 exercises for 30 seconds of peace with no rest in between exercises and you're going to perform the total circuit three times. For the first exercise, you're going to wrap a resistance band around a stable source, and you're going to get down on the ground in your normal push-up position, holding the resistance bands in both hands. If you do not have a resistance band, you can perform this exercise using just body weight. You're going to perform one rep of a push-up, and then bring one arm up like you would a front belt raise, go back down into a push-up and do the same thing on the other side. My tips for this exercise are to make sure that your core stability is on point, so you don't want your stomach to come down to the ground as you're performing the push-up and coming down to the ground. If this exercise is too difficult for you to perform with perfect form, then feel free to go to your knees and perform the exercise that way. Also, with this exercise, if your wrist begin to bother you because you are holding the ends of resistance bands, feel free to do this with one arm at a time, so you would hold the resistance band only in one hand, the other hand would be freed up, and do 15 seconds on each side. With the half-burpee pull-up thing you really want to stay aware of is the way that you're positioning your feet under your body when you're doing the burpee portion of the exercise. You want to be keeping your core really stable and contract it, so when you bring your feet in, you can get them in quickly and make sure you're pulling them right under your body and again, standing up trying to place the majority of the weight in your heels so that when you explode off the ground, you're not putting pressure in your knees. Once you're in the pull-up portion of the exercise, you really want to make sure that your core is stable because as you're coming up off the ground, you have a lot of momentum working against you to get up to that machine and to do the pull-up without sliding everywhere, you're really going to have to keep your core contracted. This exercise is actually great for people who aren't super skilled with pull-ups because you do have a lot of momentum already doing a portion of the work for you. So if you're somebody that's looking to master pull-ups, this is a great exercise to help you with that and improve your conditioning. So the body weight dip, the most important thing that you need to do is make sure that you are not coming down past 90 degrees. You can do this exercise using a different variation of angles, but the most important thing is to not break that 90 degree angle because that does place a lot of stress on the joint what you do not want. So when you perform this exercise, you need to have your feet all the way out in front of your body. Do not scoot your feet in so you're in kind of a weird chair position with your body. Even if you can only perform five reps at a time in this position and rest, that's better than performing it incorrectly. So when you're doing your bicep curls to overhead press, the two major things that you really need to be aware of are not using your own body movement to perform the bicep portion of the exercise. If you need to swing your body, you need to lower the weight. That's number one. Number two is when you're performing the overhead press, if you are standing up, it's very important that you're keeping your core stable and that your feet are shoulder width apart. If this exercise you find does place stress on your back, you can perform it sitting down. I like to perform overhead press standing up just because of what it does to the core. It really places a lot of stress on the core, but for that reason you need to make sure that you're engaging your core while doing this. The bozu plank push-up is a great exercise for defining the triceps without spending hours on tricep extensions. It's also an explosive exercise which I love for upper body because anything explosive is going to work fast twitch and fast twitch as we know builds muscle and engages the tissue responsible for muscle definition. This exercise need to be very aware again of your spine alignment. Your back should be completely flat. You should not be sinking down to the ground while you're doing this. If this exercise is too hard for you to perform in an explosive manner, simply walk your hands up the ball until you're strong enough to do it explosively. This workout can be implemented into a split one day a week just to throw your body a curve ball or it can again become kind of the main focus of your upper body workouts for a total of four to six weeks. With clients that I work with, I like to do it both way. But they kettlebell swings, make sure you're engaging your glutes, your quads and your hammies as well as your hips. You're going to keep your core nice and tight. Let the momentum of your squat bring the weight up. A lot of people think this is an upper body exercise and you just try to lift the weight but the momentum and the power really comes from your hips. For the jumping split squats, I want you to explode up as high as you can while you're switching your foot placement. I want to make sure that you're landing not flat on the balls of your feet but on your toes and rolling your foot down into a proper lunge, making sure your knee does not travel over your toes. This restless workout is great if you want to make it a finisher at the end of your workout or a starter getting you warmed up before you really hit the weights hard. Today's leg workout is going to be focused on gaining some strength. We're going to be doing three sets and ten reps of the following. Reverse lunges with back squats. This leg workout should take you about 45 minutes, so times waistin, let's get started. With the first superset, we will be doing reverse lunges paired with the back squats. With the reverse lunges, you're going to start by loading a bar just like you would for your back squat. Standing feet together, you're going to step one leg back and lunge down all the way until your knee almost touches the floor. You're going to press straight up through your front heel, bringing your back foot forward, standing into an upright position. I recommend that you stay on one side until all reps are completed for that side and then switching to the other side. And without wrecking your weight, I want you to move right into the back squats. Your feet will be a little bit wider than shoulder width apart. You're going to squat down, keeping your chest up, your shoulders back, and your core engaged through the entire lift. For your second superset, we will be doing the Bulgarians' foot squats with the pli-a squat. Again, we're doing three sets and anywhere from six to ten reps. After completing all the reps on your one leg, then you're going to transition into the other side. It's really important that you make sure your stability and your balance is in check, keeping your core tight the entire time. Your toes will be pointed out and your heels and toes both stay flat on the floor, the entire lift. You're going to squat down, grabbing the dumbbell and fully extend, really squeezing your glutes and your legs just like elevator doors closing. As soon as she have completed all the reps on one side, switch to the other side. I've seen that with people that spend at least a day stretching it a week or at this at the beginning or the end of any workout, they're going to see better results in their body just because of the fact that the cortisol is dropping and because you're lengthening the muscles out throughout the workout, you're going to get your, how you go better power output. You've got your upper traps that run from your skull and your cervical spinder your neck, and they come down and attach to your clavocose. Second, you have what's called your middle trapezius, and these run from about T1 or T4, so that upper middle back area come across and attach directly to his scapula. Last but not least, you have what's called your lower trapezius fibers. So this runs from your lower middle back or that lower thoracic spine comes up and they also attach to your scapula. Last but not least, you have your rhomblins. And while most people think of the trapezius because they're superficial or they're on the outside of the body, the rhomblins are a deep muscle and they lie underneath your trapezius. They kind of run it an angle here from your thoracic spine down to your scapula. You're going to see it a lot when you row or do any kind of horizontal pulling type movement. So with your rhomblins, even though they're not superficial, like the trapezius, you're still going to want to put a lot of emphasis on them because they're critical for front to back thickness. Now from the starting position, breathe in and begin coming down slowly until the bar nearly touches your middle chest. After a breath pause, push the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out. Focus on pushing the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position at the top of the motion. Hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. You should be in full control of the barbell at all times. Once the desired number of repetitions have been completed, return the bar to the rack.

Now exhale and curl the barbell upward by contracting your biceps. Keep your upper arms stationary while raising the barbell until it reaches shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a moment, then inhale and slowly lower the bar back to the starting position.

In the up-right position, stick your chest out and contract your back by bringing your shoulder blades back. Then slowly return to the starting position by bending your knees and simultaneously leaning the torso forward at the waist. Keep the back straight and breathe in as you execute this portion of the movement. When the weights on the bar touch the floor, you are back to the starting position and ready to perform another repetition. When the weights on the bar touch the floor, you are back in the starting position and ready to perform another repetition.

I just trained like hell. Just trained. I went on a low carb diet. A couple of the muscle heads came up to me and said, hey, you should consider competing in the masters. I compete in bodybuilding. You should be in full control of the barbell at all times. Once the desired number of repetitions have been completed, return the bar to the rack.

You also want to keep your shoulders down. A lot of times, see people lifting it up. We're doing one of these. Keep your traps out of it. So keep your shoulders down. We're going to press it out. Keep the movement nice, to control. Sometimes what I do is get a good squeeze back there. Squeeze your shoulder blades together. Don't hit the bottom here. Don't let the tension come off your muscle. Just keep it straight out. Finish your reps here. And we have flip over. Like to do is come on forward. Press it right up. It's my workout. So they have it. That's my shoulder workout. And I hope you loved watching it as much as I know you're going to love doing it. Be sure to incorporate this workout once a week into your routine. Just like every other body part. And when you get adapted to the exercises, reverse the order.
