In 1996, a former champion bodybuilder named Bill Phillips changed the way people dreamed about what was possible for their bodies. He and his supplement company, experimental and applied sciences or EAS, created a one of a kind competition that challenged regular people around the world to change their bodies and their lives like never before. The resulting book, Body For Life, became the top-selling fitness title of all time. One young entrepreneur impressed by Philips' work was Ryan Deluca, founder and CEO of Bodybuilding.com. It grew from an online storefront into a community where successful transformations happened and were on display every day. In 2013, Philips and Deluca met for the first time at Bodybuilding.com's home office in Boise, Idaho to discuss the ongoing challenge of transforming the world. What I got into writing, bodybuilding was subculture. It was very esoteric. We started to talk to our users and we realized that they didn't want to compete. They didn't really want to become a professional bodybuilder. But they wanted to learn and they wanted to transform. So we're the hardest things that I ever went through. I happened to a couple of years ago. I was at my house in California and I have my workout room on the fourth floor. And I thought, well, I want my workout room right next to my bedroom. So I'm going to walk through the gym to get to the kitchen. You know, set yourself up for success. So I did my workout. And I was just excited to get downstairs on that first step. I came down with about half my foot on the stair. And my leg was so exhausted from working out that it just buckled. I was falling forward, knees first. All I can remember is it sounded like six dry branches breaking. Pop, pop, pop. And then I grabbed this, the rail to try to stand up. My legs were like paralyzed. I couldn't move my legs. And I figured, how am I going to get off these stairs? So I pull myself up this stairs like this. Lean to get up against my bed. And I was curious as to what happened. I still in shock. And I figured out pretty quickly it was a quarter, a seven or seven and a half. So the ambulance showed up at the house. And the guys come upstairs and they put you down on one of those planks. I was riding in the back of the ambulance and I was pretty scared. I was pretty scared. So he was more looking at my neck stable because on a fall like this, you could have broke your neck. You get to the hospital. One of the surgeons comes down. He goes, what the hell did you do? And I said, well, in a way, I had a lucky fall. And he goes, what? And I said, well, I said, my neck and my back are fine. And my legs are strong as part of my body. And they took all the damage. This is a picture of my legs before surgery. This was one of the things that just began to really affect me and got very upsetting. Because I spent years and years, decades, building my calf muscles and building my quadriceps muscles. And to look down and see what they'd become in just a matter of hours. It was getting hard to get my mind around it. When I had the accident and when I was going to the hospital, I didn't really recall feeling much pain. But when I came out of surgery, it was like burning knives, just stuck in my legs. And it just absolutely shocked the heck out of me. Yeah, I screamed and then literally cried because it was so painful. And Dr. Cayman said it went good. I went well. He said it took five hours to reattach the muscles. It's the way our clothes fit, the way others perceive us, or the way we feel about ourselves as we look at our reflection. In the beginning, you might not like how you look. Bodybuilding.com changes lives. We are your free personal trainer, nutritionist, supplement expert, lifting partner and support group. Body space, our free online fitness community, is your space. It's a place for you to share your struggles, showcase your success, upload photos, make friends, stay accountable, support others, and join a network of people becoming their best selves. Body space is your one-stop social transformation station, complete with tools designed to help you achieve your health and fitness goals. When you sign up for a free body space account, we guide you through the transformation process. We help you, select your main goal, choose your goal physique based on what you want to look like. Offer an accurate timeline to help you hit that goal and set you up with friends, tools and tips for fitness success. Once you've signed up, you can set a body banner, take progress pictures, start a body log, and track your fitness journey. Make, follow, and help your friends succeed. Tell the community which members inspire you and become an inspiration. Select a custom workout, name your plan, write a quick description, select your main goal, start adding exercises, designate sets, reps and rest periods, then choose the difficulty level. Save your workout as a template, then track the workout when you're ready to hit the gym. Track when you worked out, how you felt, and how much you lifted to ensure you continually progress toward your goal. With our programs feature, you can now find a bodybuilding.com designed fitness program, or another body space members program, and track the entire program from your body calendar. Once you set a program, start date, you can sync the calendar with your phone, and track it directly from the palm of your hand. Of course, this is just the beginning. Like you, body space is always transforming, it's always getting better. We're improving navigation, usability, design, comments, profile features, and more. Also, check out Fitboard where you can post, share, and showcase your favorite photos and content. Body space is your space. We're dedicated to making it better. Join the community, help us change lives.

Caffeine comes from two primary sources. One would be chemical synthesis, which is a majority of caffeine. The other would be from the decaffeination process of coffee. For that use, it's been used for a long time and improved to enhance alertness to improve cognitive functional mental function and improve endurance. Caffeine has a pretty wide dosage range, but it's important to stay in that sweet spot. And that's three to six milligrams per kilogram of bond weight or 1.4 to about 2.7 milligrams per pound of body weight. If you go below that, it likely won't work if you go above that or even in the higher range, some people may get overstimulated and that can lead to reduced workout performance and a tough and high-resleep or no sleep that night. Your body typically adapts to training, typically adapts to the amount of calories you're eating. So if you're patient, and you adjust something, typically within two weeks, you'll see a difference. Well, I personally believe that nutrition is at least 70 to 80 percent of your results. But I think educating yourself, not only about food, what's in the food, is important. A lot of people don't understand that we actually need carbohydrates. That's our energy source. It's the first thing our body will burn. If we don't have carbohydrates, our body is not going to fuel itself. I log everything. I know how many grams of carbs I've had. I know how many grams of protein I've had, and I know exactly how many grams of fat I've had. I like to take the amount of calories that I have for the day. So let's say I'm an 1,800 calorie diet. And I divide that up by 7, sometimes 8. I think nutrient timing is extremely important. I think it's one of the most overlooked things in health and fitness is nutrient timing. I can't stress out enough. And I eat frequently every 2 hours. And I think that my body is trained that way. So when 2 hours rolls around, I know it's time to eat. My body knows it's time to eat. In the morning, I think that's one of the most important meals a day. I think that's when you should probably get at least 30% of your carbohydrates. Your body is ready, even fasting for 8 hours. And I think that it jumps out your day. It jumps out your metabolism. It fuels you. I try. I'm not perfect, but I do try. To time all of my carbs. My nutrient timing around my workout. So I try to have at least 30 grams of a complex carbohydrate about an hour before my workout. And then I try to have at least 40 grams right after my workout. Your body produces your growth hormone for muscle at night and fat helps that. So typically I have more fat at night and in the morning. Because of the intensity of my training, my diet, my calories are a lot higher than maybe even someone that's just on a normal diet. But I do adjust them. Yes, it's strength and conditioning, but we're gonna talk about CSCS specifically and then we're gonna talk about college versus life after. So we hear the word strength and conditioning consistently within a collegiate setting, but in the last few years, it's definitely leaked into the mainstream market. And that's not due to the fact that it's a concept by, you know, any means more so value than the value of certified strength and conditioning specialist is finally being realized by every day gym goal. So number one, let's just kind of start fresh and say, you know, can tell us about what a CSCS professional does and overview the job description itself, if you will. Just regarding collegiate professional or mainstream settings. Yeah, no, now to be working the NCA in most assume all professional organizations, you have to have your CSCS or CSCCA. And basically you need a college degree and then you have to pass, you know, a test, just like the ACT, the bar exam. It's the bar exam for strength coaches. I love it, friend it. So you pass that. So my question for you is how are you dictating which athletes need what within your program and why is it really a case by case spaces, even though we're all training for the same sport, that each body is gonna be different. Yeah, so we'll come in as freshmen and everyone does this, honestly every couple months is really a sports science department and we'll go through every couple months and do a battery of test, movement test, different strength tests, a dexus, so your lean body mass, text, or test. And then from there we kind of build out what you need. So like if you're someone that's really high on the strength, like the force into things, probably don't need to keep hammering that. We probably need to work more speed, velocity base. If you're someone who's really fast, but super weak, you probably need to work more in that force continuum. And if you're just kind of somewhere in the middle, like a lot of these freshmen, like you need a little bit of everything. From there we force plate test them, so they'll jump through a kind of movement, jump on a force plate. And that kind of lets us know their loading strategy. So they load more through their knees, through their hips. Do they only bend their knee, a half an inch and jump through the roof, does it take them forever to get off the ground? And then from there we kind of put them into buckets of do they need more reactivity, do they need more strength, do they more speed, do they need more mobility? And then from there we custom tailor the program for what you need during that time of the year. So we'll get all these back. I'll go to coach and be like, hey, what do you expect from this player? How do you want them to play? Is that possible? How many minutes do you expect them to play? Is that possible? And then kind of give them a realistic idea of what we can do with each athlete. Like if you're a horrible athlete, there's only so much we can do. And also if you're a high end athlete, you know we just need to work on that health time the whole time you're there. I like to use myself as the guinea pig coming from a collegiate softball background where the primary goal was to be explosive and powerful to then switching to running triathons where you're retraining your body to move for five plus hours at a time versus five seconds. So my question here is how do we approach deviating what our bodies are trained for and striving for something new and how do we do it safely and efficiently? The first thing you probably have to keep in mind is patience. We live in a society today that like everything is instant. Like instant gratification is everywhere around us. And that's actually one thing that I love about longer endurance events is it teaches you delayed gratification? You have to train for months for one race and you don't get that satisfaction until you cross the finish line? I mean, there's a lot of little winds along the way that encourage people to celebrate. But when you're shifting, say from one end of the spectrum to the other in terms of say aerobic athlete to aerobic athlete, that transition is tough, right? Because normally as kids we figure out what we're good at. Usually you'll notice at the elite level of all sports, there's some body type that tends to excel. And so usually little kids we figure out what we're really well suited to do and everybody likes winning, everybody likes being good at what they do. So we stick with that and when you continue to train and develop those qualities through your youth, you're going to get really really good at that. Then later in life, if you're trying to switch over to something else, like it can be hard to be a beginner again. And so having that patience and that understanding, knowing that failure is actually a really really good learning tool. If we go back to when we're kids, we're trying to figure out how to walk, we're trying to figure out how to throw ball, all of these things. We actually learn faster when it's not done for us and we can fail doing it. It elicits that problem solving skill a little bit better and so we learn faster. And so if we can do that in our adulthood as well, we're going to be able to again, it'll still take time, but having the patience to move through that with grace is important. I think that's a great tip to start out with. Let's go through a tangible application of this here. Let's talk about a power lifter who wants to run a half marathon, right? Where do we start? How do we start to craft a program for something like that? Yeah, so the basics are the basics, right? So they're usually pretty simple, but simple doesn't mean easy. And simple doesn't always mean fun. So we need to execute the things that have been proven, deck it up to decade to give results. So if it's at power lifter wanting to run a half marathon, it's probably starting out, okay, well, they've been doing power lifter for a long time, so they're really strong, good anaerobic athlete. What are the buckets that they haven't been training? Well, that's going to be that aerobic base more than likely. And that's actually something that you need a large bucket when you're running a half marathon. So those are two, the lifting, power lifter, or Olympic lifting, and then the half marathon, those are at two different ends of the spectrum, right? And so one great thing about training the qualities that you don't normally train is that you will have quicker adaptations when compared to trying to get those vital few persons in the sport that you've been training for a really long time. So you do get to see advancement there, but it's still, you're still not going to be at that elite level that you would with the lifting. So for instance, that one, you know, going over doing long, slow, easy aerobic work is where you're going to start for that. Are we saying about so zone two training starting to implement there, long, so periods of zone two, are we looking to implement other type of zone trainings there? What's kind of like a good first step? A good first step is going to be that slow, steady aerobic base. So zone two, even zone one recovery stuff on a five zone model, can some people use a three zone model, some people use five zone model for today's discussion. We can keep it out of five zone model. So when we're talking about zone two, it's that's below the first threshold, whether that's, you know, LT1, VT1, New Year's Breakpoint 1, whatever decision you make there, that's below that first threshold. And again, that's going to help build that person's base. They're going to increase their mitochondrial density. They're going to increase their capitalization. And so that's going to allow them to be able to utilize more oxygen efficiently. I feel like sometimes people are a bit hesitant to switch modalities, especially the later in life, it gets or kind of just stuck in their ways. They're nervous to switch, like I've been doing this for such a long time, you know, it's it's probably not that realistic at this point. You know, I would argue, and I'm sure you'll agree, but let me know, it's going to be easier to switch a modality as opposed to just coming off of the couch from not doing anything at all. I think they're going to be transferable strains that come with you when you're an analiat athlete or a power lifter moving into running because you have that strength behind you. That may be somebody who is in a more seditarian state. Well, they've got to now get strong and they have to get their aerobic work in as well. And same thing for runners. I mean, runners going to an Olympic weightlifting regimen or a powerlifting regimen, sure you may not have that strength, but you're fit, right? You have the aerobic capacity behind you to get some of that endurance lifting done. So, I don't know. I don't know where I was really going with that, but I think my point is that I think there are a lot of people who tend to box themselves into a specific modality, and then it really isn't, you know, there's never a such thing as being too late of making that switch to something else you want to try. 100% and when you think about it, switching from one modality to the other, like you said, is going to be easier than coming straight off the couch. You can't even think about it from a team sport perspective to a solo sport perspective. It's going to be there's different things that come with that. And some of that is like the mindset or just the interaction that you have, the accountability you have to yourself and keeping yourself motivated versus having a team to be there for you. And the answer to that is no. The reason why is when you're doing strength training, you're working your fast twitch muscle fibers. And so again, by definition, when we're in zone two, we're working slow twitch muscle fibers. Let's can you explain what VO2 Max is to our listeners and layments turn just to understand what is actually being measured with this test? Yeah, so VO2 Max is your body's ability to utilize oxygen. So the better structures you have, so let's say the more amount of conjured density you have, the bigger amount of conjured, you have the greater proliferation you have, the capillary network that you have going to yourselves, if that's greater, you're going to be able to deliver more oxygen to the cells. If you have a higher red blood cell count, the carrying capacity of your blood is enhanced, and so you can bring more oxygen. So there's a lot of breakdown points in the human system, so a cardiovascular system, respiratory system, metabolic system, that can kind of staunch your VO2 Max, and so when we're doing our testing in the lab, we get a really good look under the hood of what's going on. Oh, is somebody hyperventilating and offloading too much carbon dioxide, is somebody just having a really low max heart rate. Whatever those issues are, we can get a very good understanding to look at it and then have training and nutrition protocol prescriptions to try and enhance that, whether that's through training and supplementation, again, trying to fix not fix, but enhance the structures that they're working with, through again, VO2 Max intervals, or base training, or zone three, like increasing the size of the left ventricle, so we can pump more blood through the system with each beat of the heart. So there's a lot that that goes into that. Last point on VO2 Max here, what is the difference between getting this measurement from this garment on my wrist versus going into a facility that's a equipped to measure it. Let's say more appropriately, right? I myself have had VO2 tests done, I'll shout out the spoke treatments here, and what's that? What that has allowed me to understand, like, I burned through my glucose pretty quickly, and that has helped me adjust some of my fueling strategies when I go after something like a 70.3, I probably need to start a little bit sooner than what I was actually doing. So that's just one of the many benefits and insights that you can gain from something like that, but tell us a little bit about the difference between this here on my wrist versus actually going into the lab to get this measured. Yeah, so the the risk-based, the optical sensor on your watch, your device, or wearable, is not going to be near as accurate, because it's measuring the light refraction from the blood, and it's throwing it in an algorithm and estimating what your VO2 Max is going to be. When you're going in and I actually did a VO2 Max test and recently met a ball crate test this morning with one of my athletes, and so what you're doing is you're putting on the mask and you're measuring the amount of oxygen that they're taking in and measuring the amount of carbon dioxide that they're blowing off. And from that, that's how you were able to see, oh, I'm utilizing this, this many carbohydrates when I'm working at this intensity. So a healthy individual will, should be burning more fat at lower intensity and less carbohydrate at lower intensity. As that intensity rises up, you're going to see that fat curve start to drop and that carbohydrate curve start to increase to where if you're working all out max effort, you're burning all carbohydrates in zero percent fat. So again, having that little chart that graph of like, okay, at 150 beats, I'm burning this percentage of fat carbs, 156, you will see that change and then you can use that and raise strategy to be able to say, oh, you know, I need to taper it down or I'm going to have to ingest more carbs and that's going to be over my limit because I know that's going to upset my stomach or whatever that may be. So using it as that, but also understanding, do you have good fat utilization capabilities even in those lower intensities? And so when we're doing a resting metabolic rate test, we can see at rest the cellular health of an individual just by that one metric alone. Do they tend to burn more fat for fuel at rest or more carbohydrates? And you'll notice in a lot of diabetics and pre-diabetics that they primarily burn carbohydrates. An interesting thing about athletes and you'll see this with like a lot of crossfitters and people that just hammer themselves and all they do is high intensity stuff. They never work on that lowerobic base. As soon as they start to increase the intensity, just a little bit, their body has been trained to go, oh, what we're about to go all out here. We better start dumping glucose into the system and because that's what we're going to need. And so they have a very sensitive shift in, in a burning a lot more carbohydrates than they should at those lower intensities. So you do learn a lot about yourself, about how your body works, by going into the lab and getting those measurements. And so the amount of oxygen that you're taking in at that highest level, there comes a point where you had a peak. And there's a, there is a difference between a VO2 max test and a VO2 peak test. A VO2 max test is a test where you get to the end of the test and the oxygen consumption has gotten to the top of what you can see. A VO2 peak test is where there's actually a peak in that oxygen consumption and then it will actually either plateau or slightly come back down and kind of go back and forth in between that. And that's how you know you've hit your true VO2 peak. Is if you see that at the end of the, the graph, the end of the test at those higher intensities, same with your max heart rate. If you're trying to get a true max heart rate test, you want to be able to climb your heart rate to a point to where you're continually increasing the intensity. But your heart rate hits a spot where it plateau's and it can no longer go higher. That's how you can know for certain that you've done a max heart rate test. And so with that indirect calimetry that you're, with the mass that you're again measuring the oxygen consumption carbon dioxide output, you get a true value of how much oxygen your body is utilizing. Whereas the watch again, it's not measuring your oxygen consumption, it's just guessing at what your blood is doing, putting it in an algorithm. And interestingly enough, and this probably isn't the case, but whenever I've compared the VO2 max results that I've gotten with my athletes to the ones that track it on their watch, for some reason, it's always 10 beats lower on the watch than it is in the actual test. So if you think your VO2 max is low because you look at your watch, well, it might be a little bit higher, so that's something good to think about. Yeah, there's a good takeaway. Thanks for bringing that down, Lance. Last heart rate stat that I want to nerd out on and before we get into our final piece of the discussion here today, heart rate variability. This has been a big one that's come up as well as of late. You've seen whoop start to inject that into their dashboard, other wearables are doing it as well. Your personal opinion is this a fair metric to be measuring on, again, a wrist wearable, how accurate do we think this really is. But then also, how important is this metric, right? I feel like five, six, seven years ago, no one was talking about HRV, right? So number one, what is heart rate variability? The number two, what's the best way of us measuring that word, Lance, do we need to really necessarily be measuring this, especially more so gen pop? Is this something we need to wrap our head around? Right. Heart rate variability is the milliseconds of variability between each heartbeat. And so your heart isn't exactly a beating once every second. It might beat 1.01 seconds and then 0.98 seconds. And so there is a little bit of variability there. The more variability that you have, the better it is because that means that your body's sympathetic nervous system is more in control, or sorry, I should say, parasympathetic nervous system is more in control. So that rest and digest system. If your heart variability is lower, that means your sympathetic system is a more in control. And that's your fire flight system. So if you're chronically stressed out, anxious all the time, you may find that your HRV is much lower than when you get it really good night sleep, or a couple of really good night sleep if you're chronically sleep-deprived, when you're well hydrated, when you're well rested, if you use yourself time to fully recover, so that's an important part is understanding that in like when your parasympathetic system is in the driver's seat versus your sympathetic system. It's not necessarily super important. I would say for the general population, but when you talk about athletes that are trying to optimize every little percentage point that they can and do it in a safe manner, they may have like a really hard training session on the schedule for the next day and then they wake up and they see that their HRV is plummeted for whatever reason. It can guide their decision on if they should do that workout at all or if they should taper it, maybe cut it in half, give themselves a full rest day, whatever that may be. So I would say it's more for the athlete and then with your question of, is it even accurate? Again, it comes back to quality and quality out. If you don't have a good measuring device and we go back to the optical sensor on your on your wrist-based wearable, that may not give you the best reading. If you can get it with a heart rate strap, that's going to be the gold standard and if you can get it first thing when you wake up before you've started moving around and gotten your heart rate up, like just sit there and measure that's going to be again the gold standard. And so with people one thing that we have to keep in mind is I can't compare my HRV to yours. I can't say, oh, yours is 96 and minus 72 so you know you're more covered than I am. But we all have a certain range that will kind of plan depending on how fit we are and how we're training. So the most important thing to do and this is really true with most things, even going back to the O2 Max is it's not the actual number on the day, it's the trend over time. So if your HRV is is chronically low for, you know, a male, it's 32 or whatever it is, then okay, well that may just be your normal set point. But if you see it rise or dip, now you know that something's happening. So looking for the trend over time is important. Same with your V02 Max, everybody has a genetic ceiling. You can push it a little bit higher and you look for that trend. But the number the number itself isn't like an end all be all. Yes, we want it to be high when we compare it to norms in terms like when we're looking at our health and longevity. But the most important thing is can we increase it? So right now because I'm in between two of the races that are really close together I'm just recovering this week so I'm only doing massage, did some cold plunge to I'm still my legs, my feet are still swollen so trying to get as much inflammation out of the body before I start training up again but when I am in actual training block to where I can push things I'm training six days a week and I'll have one full rest recovery day because that's where you actually get all of those positive adaptations right you you have stress then you have rest and that's what you equals growth if you don't have that rest component then you're just perpetually breaking your body down and you're never fully realizing those benefits and I find a lot of ultra under because you have a lot of type A people that do like ultra and triathlons they'll hammer hammer hammer day in day out and never give their body a full rest day and I'm like you're really not optimizing like all this hard work that you're putting in. So I think it's a very important at least once every 10 days to have a full rest recovery day even just to leave your central nervous system chill out and recover. So for me I find that for my body once every week works really well to have that full complete rest day and then in that I'll do during the training I'll do one to two strength training sessions and that'll be focused on maximal strength because with the ultra-end distance running you're filling up those buckets of your aerobic base and the slow twitch muscle fibers and so we talked earlier about training the entire force velocity training all of your energy systems so when you're in the gym if you're doing medium to light weight and you're doing 20-30 reps of something you're training muscular endurance and you're getting that out there when you're running. So I like to say to the endurance athletes you know do build strength in the gym build endurance on your runs don't try to build more endurance in the gym you're just overfilling that endurance bucket so I'm trying to fill those buckets probably where they belong I'll have two long runs during the week and I'll do them on back to back days usually a Friday Saturday or a Saturday Sunday and what that allows me to do is to safely accumulate a ton of volume and a really short amount of time safely because you're getting that little bit of rest and recovery in between so I would never really for myself or any of my athletes for a training run program more than 30 miles so during a peak week of training it would be say a 30 mile Saturday and then a 20 mile Sunday so you're still accumulating 50 miles of volume on that weekend in a 36 hour time frame but you're not at the risk of injury near as much as if you were to hammer that out all at once. From there I also make sure I had at least one high intensity effort I usually do two and again the high intensity efforts are dependent on where I am in this season the further away I am the further the further out that I am from the race and the event the more I'll be working at the top end of the spectrum the VO2 max stuff the threshold stuff as I get closer to the race I need to get more race specific so I'll do a lot more zone three tempo interval stuff so for my high intensity days and then from there the other days are filled with three to four easy runs and then again lots of recovery you can't train what you don't recover from and so that's another thing I see is like people put in a lot of volume a lot of intensity but not put the time into recovery and that is when your body adapts and you get stronger. The first reaction to something like this for somebody who's never done something like this is who has the time. To get in the starting position, raise the pulleys to a setting above your head. Next, select the resistance you like to use. Then while holding a pulley in each hand, step forward in front of an imaginary straight line between both pulleys while pulling your arms together in front of you. Your torso should have a small forward bend from the waist. This will be your starting position. Now with the slight bend in your elbows, breathe in and extend your arms straight out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Then using your chest, bring your arms back to the starting position as you breathe out. Make sure you use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights. Hold for a second at the starting position, then repeat the movement for the prescribed number of repetitions.

New below a high pulley with a rope attached. Grasp the cable rope attachment and lower the rope into your hands or next to your face. Flex your hips slightly and allow the weight to arch your back. This will be your starting position. Now while keeping your hips stationary, exhale and flex your waist as you contract your abs. Your elbow should lower toward the middle of your thighs. Hold it the bottom contracted position for a moment, then inhale and slowly return to the starting position. Make sure to keep constant tension on your abs throughout the movement.

I touch a rope to the bottom pulley of the machine. Grasp the rope with both hands and extend your arms with your hands directly above your head. The palms of your hands should be facing each other. Your elbows should be close to your head while your arms are perpendicular to the floor with your knuckles aimed at the ceiling. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and slowly lower the rope behind your head while keeping your arms stationary. Then you lowering the rope until your triceps are fully stretched. Then exhale and use your triceps to return the rope back to the starting position.

Your serratus anterior is one of three muscles that allows your shoulder blade to rotate or create upward rotation. So that's something I want you to know. When you're walking away from this serratus anterior, it's not just great if you got a built physique like Craig, but it's critically important if you want to keep your shoulders healthy as well. So with that being said, the first exercise we're going to demonstrate is a dumbbell in client bench press. If you technique points as far as setting up, make sure your abs are nice and tight. Whenever possible, keep your feet on the ground. You keep your abs in your legs tight. You're going to be able to move more weight. From this position, he's locked in and he's just going to press the dumbbells overhead. Now one thing I always like to cue my clients to do is to tuck the elbows slightly when they come down. If your elbows are really flared out to the side, it puts a lot more stress and torque on your shoulders. So think about tucking the elbows slightly on the way down, full range of motion and then finish strong at the top. When you're doing an incline bench, you're really using all three heads of your pecs. You're using the clavicular head. You're using the sternal head. You're using the abdominal head. But when you go on an incline, or when you start to flex those shoulders, that's when you're really going to bring out an attack that clavicular head of your pet. So if you're having problems filling in the top portion of that chest, make sure you get some incline venting or some incline flies into your program. One final point. When you incline bench, if you have any kind of shoulder issue or this causes any discomfort, move to a neutral grip where your hands are facing each other and then try it again. This is going to give you just a little bit of breathing room for your rotator cuff to move and operate and chances are it's going to feel a heck of a lot better. And then from this position, he's just going to keep soft elbows, get a nice stretch through his pecs. And as you guys can imagine, you can just see those pecs kind of opening up and lengthening. Grab the pull-up bar with the palms of your hands facing your torso and a grip closer than shoulder width. Next with both arms extended in front of you holding the bar, bring your torso back about 30 degrees while creating a curvature in your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position. Now exhale and pull your torso upward until the bar nearly touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and upper arms down and back. This is in trade on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position and keep the elbows close to your body. Your upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only your arms should move. Your forearm should do no work other than hold the bar. After a second in the contracted position, while breathing in, slowly lower your torso back to the starting position where your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.

So it's safe to say that finding the right shoe not only can help you perform better but it can play a role in injury prevention right and I don't think that consideration gets taken a whole bunch by Jen Pop right. I'm going to say like Olympic weightlifting for the perfect example. You want that really flat solid surface underneath you. I mean you should if you're going for Olympic weightlifting investment repair weightlifting shoes. I mean you've reviewed a bunch of weightlifting shoes. What would you say about weightlifting specifically? Yeah, weightlifting shoes can be a fantastic tool for anybody who wants to get into the sport of weightlifting or if you are for example across pedathlete and doing weightlifting on a regular basis. Or if you're just a recreational lifter and you do want to explore that type of footwear for getting more into clean, snatches, etc. They can be really useful because with a weightlifting shoe, the midsole is going to be entirely different. Think of this as like you're going to your toolbox, you're finding this specific five footwear for this activity. They can also be great for squats because of this type of construction that they have. And three calls on to weightlifting shoes to take into account for this sport is when you're doing any formal weightlifting you generally want to be catching weight with a more upright torso in a deeper range of motion. So catching a clean at the bottom or squatting to depth for example, what a weightlifting shoe is going to have is it's going to have an elevated heel. That is going to put your foot into a planter flex position before you physically start lifting. Which then can allow the knees to track a little bit further, which can then allow you to feel like you can sink your hips back a bit more, give more depth while maintaining more upright torso. And so with a weightlifting shoe, three things to think about here, similar to our cross-running shoe is the height of the heel. If you know for example that you struggle with mobility or you struggle keeping an upright torso in catching weight in a clean or if you're just having trouble with depth in the squat, a higher heel can generally be a good bat, but most weightlifting shoes will have a heel height around like 0.75 inches. And that's usually a good bat for most the second thing that we're lifting shoe will have to your point is like that nice stable outsole or that nice very firm outsole. And that's designed to allow you to catch the weight from a nice stable context while also really feeling the floor and getting a nice grip. Generally weightlifting shoes will have a full rubber outsole. If you're buying a weightlifting shoe that doesn't have a solid pass on that shoe, it's not going to be worth it. So you have a higher heel elevation, you have a very stable and grippy outsole. And you also have similar to the cross-treating shoe, a reinforced upper but with weightlifting shoes, you'll generally have straps. Or even like a bow-alacing system like on the EIT's Lesting models that give you additional security. And this prevents any form of spillover because to our point like if you're catching a clean and cross-treating shoe with a really loose upper and you're spilling over, a weightlifting shoe will have like dual straps to really lock that foot down generally like leather upper or synthetic upper that are really going to lock the feet down to prevent any form of spillover. But all that to say yeah weightlifting shoes can be a super specific tool and another question that I get asked with weightlifting shoes while we're on this topic is do beginners need them. Does everybody need them? And in most cases probably not. But I do think they're really useful tool to just have in your toolbox and generally we're lifting shoes will last you a while because they will offer just a different way to train. I think it's very important too for example squat with a zero-dropper or flat foot position but then also with a weir lifting shoe depending on what your goals are. I think a lot of folks into your point with like the injury context is we often don't realize if something's a problem until it is and a lot of this could just easily be prevented by using the right tools at the right times and it's like a great example is like okay you're front squatting and you're squatting bearer foot and you don't realize like what you get to a threshold like your torso is dropping so much that you can't physically move efficiently a weightlifting shoe could actually help prevent all that allow you to perform to your fullest and then you could also just implement any form of other squat variation and leg variation with a flatter foot position so you still get to train in that range of motion or whatnot. allowing those intrinsic deeper muscles to strengthen that might not be strengthened in shoes has been really important in the sense of why people are adapting this type of training number two I think just the appropriate set of elements of feeling the ground below the feet can be really powerful for folks when they feel it for the first time I feel so balanced I feel so stable like this feels The goal today's workout is to be able to complete the entire process in as little as 30 minutes. The first time you go through it, you might not be able to pull it off in 30 minutes. So run through it, get it down pat, and then work on your speed and get it down to as little as you can. We're going to start off with workout today with buy-sips. We're going to do an exercise called 21 which involves three portions to the movement. First part of the contraction is 50% of the contraction. You're going to do that for seven. Second part of the movement is the top contraction part that upper 50% of the contraction for seven, and then you're going to complete the movement with the full range for an additional seven. Hence the 21. We're going to start out with 30 pound dumbbells. We're going to use this little rest as possible, get down to the 25s, 20s, 15s, and tens. When you first start out, it's not that tough, especially with a 50% contraction movement and not that heavy. But as you start getting a little bit further, even as the weights come down, you'll continue to challenge yourself. We're going to slide over to an inclined bench, and you're going to do another extension with your elbow pointed out that's going to hit a different head on the trice up here. If the third movement that you're going to do in the trice set is back to the bench as a close grip bench press, again hitting the trice to fatigue. As soon as you complete that movement, we're going to drop down to 25s and then we're going to do it all over again, staying in that 10 to 15 rep range burn out each time everything you have, and we're going to reduce it all the way down to the 10 bond dumbbells, and you won't have much left, even with little 10 pound dumbbells. We're going to the third and final movement of our weight training shoulders. This is the last part you're going to be fatigued from bise and trice, but we're moving quickly and we've got to get this done in 30 minutes. So you're going to slide over to the 30 pound dumbbells and you're going to do three movements all over again. We're going to start with the lateral raise for 10 reps. We're going to go to overhead press for 10 reps and a front raise for 10 reps. You're going to drop the sets down to 25s, 20s, 15s again down to 10s, and even though 10 pound dumbbells are not heavy, you're going to feel them by the end. Now we're done with the weight training portion of this and we're going to finish out with 10 minutes of high intensity interval training cardio. We're going to put that grade and 15. We're going to start with 60 seconds of walking and then we're going to alternate that with 60 seconds of running at this fastest pace as your body can handle. You'll use the next 60 seconds to recover and keep alternating that until you hit your 10 minute mark. When you complete those 10 minutes, you will have finished up a 30 minute high intensity by try shoulder and cardio vascular workout. With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position. Begin the first pull by driving through the heels extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees. Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion accelerate by extending the hips, knees and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight. At the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back with the arms still extended. As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery. Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have a risen twist-dunning position. The second phase is the jerk, which raises the weight overhead. Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly and reverse the direction as powerfully as possible. Drive through the heels to create as much speed and force as possible and be sure to move your head out of the way of the bar as it leaves the shoulders. At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment, the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athletes effort to push the bar up will drive the feet down. The feet should be split with one foot forward and one foot back. Receive the bar with the arms locked out overhead. Return to a standing position.

Slide back on a flat bench. Use a closed grip to lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms straight. This will be your starting position. Now inhale and slowly lower the bar down until it nearly touches your middle chest. Be sure to keep your elbows close to your torso at all times to maximize tricep involvement. After a brief pause at the bottom contracted position, exhale and raise the bar back to the starting position using your triceps to push the bar upward.

Sit at the pull down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Make sure you adjust the knee pad to fit snug against your legs. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the weights and allow you to perform the exercise correctly. Grip the bar closer than shoulder width with the palms of your hands facing forward. Both arms should be extended in front of you holding onto the bar. Lean your torso back about 30 degrees to create a small curvature in your back and stick your chest out. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and bring the bar down until it nearly touches your upper chest. Draw your shoulders and upper arms back to do this. Once you reach the bottom contracted position, concentrate on squeezing your back muscles. Your upper torso should remain stationary during the movement and only your arms should move. So make sure to use your forearms only to hold the bar and not to pull it down. After a brief pause at the bottom contracted position, inhale and slowly raise the bar back to the starting position with your arms fully extended and your lats stretched.

Sit down on a flat bench with one dumbbell in front of you. Use your right arm to grasp the dumbbell with an underhand grip. Place the back of your right arm against your inner right thigh. Your arm should be extended and the dumbbell should be above the floor. This will be your starting position. Now while holding your upper arm stationary, exhale and curl the weight upward while concentrating on the biceps. Continue to raise the weight until your bicep is fully contracted and the dumbbell is as shoulder level. Hold the top contracted position for a moment. Then inhale and slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. To maximize the benefit of this exercise, avoid swinging the weight at any time.

Life flat on your back with your feet flat on the ground or resting on a bench with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. If they are elevated on a bench, place them about three inches apart and point your toes inward so they touch. Place your hands on both sides of your head and keep your elbows in. Be sure to press the small of your back down on the floor to help better isolate your abdominal muscles. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and slowly begin to roll your shoulders off the floor. Your shoulder should come up off the floor about four inches while your lower back remains on the floor. At the top of the movement flex your abdominals and hold for a brief pause. Then inhale and slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position.

Then while breathing in, lower yourself down more slowly with your torso leaning forward less than 45 degrees. Your elbow should flare out slightly until you feel a slight stretch in your chest. Once you feel the stretch, use your chest to bring your body back up to the starting position while breathing out. Also remember to squeeze the chest at the top of the movement for a moment to get the maximum benefit of the exercise.

To get in the starting position, hold your body at arms length with your arms nearly locked above the bars. Now inhale and slowly lower yourself downward. Your torso should remain upright and your elbows should stay close to your body. This helps better focus on tricep involvement. Lower yourself until there's a 90 degree angle form between the upper arm and forearm. The next inhale and push your torso back up using your triceps to bring your body back to the starting position.

Slide down on a flat bench with a dumbbell and each hand resting on top of your thighs. Then using your thighs to help raise the dumbbells. The dumbbells should be just to the sides of your chest with your upper arm and forearm creating a 90 degree angle. Be sure to maintain full control of the dumbbells at all times. This will be your starting position. As you breathe out, use your chest to push the dumbbells up. Lock your arms at the top of the lift and squeeze your chest. Hold for a second and then begin to come down slowly. Ideally lowering the weight should take about twice as long as raising it. When finished, don't drop the dumbbells next to you as this can be dangerous. Instead you'll want to return to the seated position and place the dumbbells on top of your thighs. To do this, simultaneously push with your upper body while slightly kicking with your lower to provide the momentum needed to help you return to the seated position. From this position you can safely place the dumbbells on the floor.

But somebody who's maybe just trying to shed a couple pounds and gain a few pounds of muscle, what's your advice for them? Okay, my advice for them. Figure out what you're doing right now, honestly. Not the whole, okay, I'm going to keep a food journal, so I'm not eating any more donuts. Like actually look at where you are. And the mistake people make is trying to have a better peak. So they, they're like man, last Monday, I ate 90% perfect. This Monday, I'm eating 100% perfect. Or I only screwed up my diet on Wednesday. Instead of doing that, instead of looking at raising the peak, if you look at raising the floor. So never doing worse or as bad as you did the week previous. So you ate 19 donuts last week. No offense to anyone who likes donuts. I don't know what that's. That's my target today, but I'm going after donuts. You had 19 donuts last week, but on Monday you only had one. So instead of thinking, okay, Monday I'm having zero. Go this week, I'm going to eat less than 19. And if you can continually eliminate your worst habits or making them less bad, you improve significantly faster mathematically. And we can break that down later in a video later. I show you the numbers because it's magic. But it's also easier. If I want to improve my average in high school, on a high school student. And I've got a 90 in English, but I've got a 40 in math. I can get a 10% improvement in English going from 90 to 100. But 90 to 100 is a lot of work. I can get a 10% improvement in math going from 40% to 50. I get that same 10% improvement. It's a lot easier to do. The worst something is the easier it is to improve it. There's a lot more low hanging fruit. That's what people should be focused on. You don't need a perfect diet. You need one that isn't as bad as someone you have right now. And then once you get used to that, a little bit less bad again. I want to kick this conversation off by defining what is a one-rette max, and what's the benefit of testing it? Great. Question. So, one-rette max is exactly what it sounds like. It is the most amount of weight or the maximum weight you can perform for a single repetition in a movement. So, if you can bench 200 pounds twice, it might be your two-rette max, but it is not your ultimate one-rette max. Now, the caveat on that outside of a professional strongman contest or a power lifting contest, I would cap people's one-rette max at either the most amount of weight they can handle or the most amount of weight they can handle without their form breaking down. So, if you start bench pressing and your form is getting kind of messed up, your shoulders are coming forward, like you're barely squeezing it out and you're like, I think I could do five more pounds as a coach, I would not be permitting that. So, whatever you can you can hit for a single rep with good form. So, that's never going to be picture perfect at a one-rette that would be what that is. Now, in terms of the importance of it, as with everything, the importance of something is going to be relative to what the goal is or what the driving purpose is. But for everyone having an understanding of M, I get stronger or not matters. It doesn't matter of your grandma or grandpa who's saying, like, man, five years from now, I'm going to be able to stand up off the couch, getting stronger will hope and sure that happens. It doesn't matter if you're you're looking for performance, it doesn't matter if you're competitive athlete, if you just like being strong, having a metric till M, I'm moving in the right direction, M, I get stronger. Your one-rette max is the ultimate measure of that. That's what I'm telling you. So, how do we go about testing it and does it differ by the type of left-over testing? So, it doesn't differ based on the left, but in terms of testing it, essentially what you're going to do is whatever you would do to warm up generally. So, you're going to get yourself to the point that you feel good, whether you do a hip warm-up for squats or you're warming up your shoulders, elbows for bench press, whatever happens to be. From there, my advice always is to conserve the number of reps you do. So, let's say, I'm going to work up to a one-rette max on squat. I get squat 135. I don't know 100 times. I'm going to squat it for five reps, maybe. And then maybe I go to 185 and I squat that for three. And then I'm probably doing doubles or singles. So, sets of two sets of one all the way up. I'm trying to conserve as much energy as possible. Well, I'm climatizing myself to more and more weight because you won't be neurologically or physically ready for a one-rette max when you're cold. Or let's say I've warmed up and I've squatted 225 and I think I'm going to squat 500. Jumping straight to 500, I will not physically be ready for. Physically, neurologically, mentally, emotionally. Like, I won't be there. So, very progressive weight jumps that get smaller as you get closer to where you're going and maximizing how much energy you keep in the tank is key to building up and actually testing it. You mentioned concerning energy. I think this is a huge one. This is a mistake that I often see. Sometimes it's at the end of their day. Sometimes they do a very, very elaborate workout. Sometimes they do some cardio just to get a sweat in and now they're doing that progression that you just mentioned working up to it. By then, I mean, they're shot. You're done. Right? So, I mean, let's take it as far out as the couple of days leading up to this. Right? So, say, you're really dialed in. You're dedicated to finding this one-wrap max. You've been working hard. Let's say over the last eight weeks and it's time to retest again whether you're doing it on your owner with your coach. What are the days leading up to a one-wrap max or a testing day look like? And what should that day, you know, leading up to the time of the test even look like? So, leading up to it, five, four to seven days out. I would not be training that lift. Hard at all. And if it was a deadlift, I'd keep it at least a week out, a squat, maybe about a week. A bench press you could probably get away with. A moderate amount of benching four or five days out. And then you're just going to let yourself recover. So, there's this idea in training that you stress your body, your capacity diminishes as you stress your body. So, the weakest you should be on a bench press is at the very end of your bench press workout. From there, your body starts to recover. And essentially, if you picture like a dip and a raise, it'll come back up beyond where you started at before the stress. And that's called super compensation. So, you don't just recover, you recover plus a little bit. So, in the time before you're trying to give yourself that downtime to make sure that you get to the height of the peak of recovery you can get to. And ideally, that's where you're testing. In terms of the day of my advice, if you're at the point where you're seriously testing one Ritmax and planning it into your program, you should be self aware of what makes you feel good. When I go do that. So, if I was going to do a max out squat, I'd probably get all you can eat sushi like two hours before and come in like, oh, feeling like a big balloon. Because that is something I like. Some people when they're lifting heavy prefer to be a little bit hungry or just, like, evenly satiated. Now, I think people severely underestimate what a 10 pound jump or a 15 pound jump or a 20 pound jump. So what as a coach, Craig, what type of expectations do you set with your clients? And of course, that can differ. But what kind of mindset do you get them in in terms of how big those jumps are in between programs? So there are two things I do with that. One is I like to talk in terms of percentages. If you bench, I actually know we'll do this backwards. If I bench a hundred pounds, but you bench 400 pounds, a 10 pound jump for me is 10 percent and for you it's what? 2.5. Somebody check that math. You know, let me know in the comments. But it's a significantly higher percentage for me. That's why at gyms you'll get dumbbells that go 5 pounds, 7 and a half, 10, 12 and a half, 15, 17 and a half, 20. But you won't see a dumbbell that goes 80 pounds, 82.5 pounds, 85 pounds because the percentage jump is so much smaller. So looking at your strength relative, relative to that improvement with the percentage, we'll give you a gauge on it. Like, oh man, that was only 10 pounds. 10 pounds is a lot. If you woke up 10 percent taller, or you woke up with 10 percent more net worth, or you drove 10 percent faster everywhere. Your weighed 10 percent lighter. Yeah, it's a massive change. Like, that's really big. 10 pounds doesn't sound like a lot. But 10 percent of your bench press or your swat or your dead, that sounds like a ton. Rounding out today, Craig. We're going to move into the topic of training for mass versus training for power. So there's a difference in training styles when we're training to put on muscle, versus training for power or say performance. So I want to, I want to break open a couple of things, reps, schemes, programming styles, splits, all of the fun stuff. So first of all, break down what is the biggest difference between training for muscle versus training for power or performance? So when we're talking about power and performance, there's a pretty broad spectrum, even within power and how people use it or performance. So my, the biggest difference. Training to build muscle, training to grow muscle to body build. Yeah, aesthetics. We're focusing on aesthetics. We want to get the, we want to get, you know, jacked. Yeah, which is awesome. Like, if you're not jacked, if you haven't been jacked, you should try it. It's great. But the biggest difference between training for aesthetics and training for a power or performance model, regardless of the specifics within it. Training for aesthetics is about workload. And there's a million different ways to skin that cat, but it's about workload. Training for power and performance is about velocity. It's about the speed, the bar or the thing you're, you're lifting, is moving. And the velocity you train in is how you zero in on the particular outcome you want. But it becomes one is about total work. One is about speed of the movements. So let's get into the granular details of the difference between those two as well. Give me the examples of the, of the reps schemes in terms of how we're training for hypertrophy, right, versus power. So if we're talking power, we're talking like explosive power output. Let's say for an athlete. If I was looking at aesthetics, I probably give people two options. The first being more suited to a beginner. And the second being a little more advanced. But I'll give you both. And then compare it power. For a beginner, you could do the standard. I'm doing five sets of 10 on my leg press or five set the 10 on squat. I'm looking for a large amount of total work. With somebody more advanced, it might be I'm doing two heavy sets of squats. And then I'm doing a back off set of squats where I cut the weight 25-30 percent and I go to failure. So you're again looking for total work and stress on the particular muscles. If we were to contrast that to something for power, if we were to take, so Westside Barbel has something called the dynamic method, which is about building explosive power. And if you were to squat with the dynamic method, dynamic method, excuse me, you'd be doing 10 to 12 sets of squat with 60 to 80 percent of your one-ret max. But you'd be doing sets of two with very low rest and the focus would be on how fast you're moving the bar on that movement. So one is about practicing a physical quality. That's power. I'm practicing being explosive. I'm practicing being powerful. The other is a total work and steadily increasing that over time. To increase my performance, I don't necessarily have to increase my total work over time if I'm talking explosive output, but I need to increase the quality of that work. I need to get better at being explosive. So I practice being explosive. To build muscle, I need to slowly increase my amount of work over time so that continued stress helps me add the muscle I'm looking for. And with Stumi and you mentioned rest time in here as well and correct me if I'm wrong here, but when we're looking at more performance or power athletes, I'm thinking, let's put into athlete terms like a baseball player or soccer player. These are people who need to have one step explosiveness. So the work that they're doing in the weight room, even things like, you know, I don't know, basketball and some of these things where it's very quick burst of energies that is spent. So I would assume you mentioned it's a lower rest. So we're doing the two reps at a lower rest, how much rest? Like 30 to 40 seconds. Sure. Because we want to train our energy system to be able to handle that load with minimal rest versus if we're training for aesthetics, one could argue, I mean, you have more time. We're almost getting to full recovery. I would absolutely argue that. I would directly argue that actually. I think that's 100% right. Where does, you know, where does a cardiovascular role come into play when we're training these two different goals, you know, more of the hypertrophy? I mean, it can be argued that it is a less of a heart strain for that type of training versus your power and performance. Completely. So if I was training strictly for aesthetics and I was also concerned about general heart health, I'd be doing really low intensity cardio, for anywhere between three and five days a week. Now let's say it was 20 or 30 minutes. I'd be doing that for heart health. I'd be doing it for recovery. Depending on when you're eating and what you're eating, it can aid in digestion, but there are a huge amount of benefits to just regular cardio, even for aesthetic aesthetic goals. If you're like, I don't care if I die in 10 years. I just want to be jacked. Low intensity steady state cardio will help you get more jack too and maybe prevent you from dying in 10 years. When it comes to athletic goals, it needs to be much more specific. What is expected of this athlete? A baseball player and a boxer. Both need explosiveness. They both need to be able to turn that on when they want it, but one of them needs a much bigger gas tank for that. Like a baseball player, what if they hit a home run or they hit a really good ball and have to run the basis. They're only doing that. They get a lot of rest afterwards. For the most part, it's swing the bat, hit the ball sprint a first or sprint from first to second or push off, you know, you're leg to get to backhand that grounder. Yeah, do you know what baseball? I was a demon self-alper. Whoa, hey, I don't know anything about baseball. I want to go to my daughter's team. Well, I needed a parent volunteer. I bought two baseball books on Amazon. I'd never hit a baseball. I don't know if I'd ever thrown what like I had no idea it was going. Which had off-line correct. Yeah, I picked up DIC example. So baseball players need that same explosiveness, but then get a lot of downtime. A boxer needs almost this continual flow of explosiveness with a ton of work over time. Like they're constantly working. Well, they're going to get knocked unconscious. So looking at those helps you manipulate a performance program specifically to the goal. So performance programs need to be much more particular as you get to higher and higher levels. Like when my daughter was playing baseball versus you playing D1, the level of specificity requires much more significant for you obviously. But as you move forward in performance, that specificity needs to be there. And everything in your program should be justified by that. Yeah, now I think we'd be remiss, you know, if we didn't really clarify majority of the people who are listening to this, probably just want to gain a couple pounds of muscle, lose a couple pounds of fat, live a little bit longer and just be all around healthier. But I will also make the argument that there are a lot of folks out there, a lot of adults out there who maybe have hobbies that they're very passionate about. And they do want to excel at those. Stand up straight while holding an easy curl bar at the wide outer handle. The palms of your hand should be facing forward and slightly tilted inward due to the shape of the bar. Keep your elbows close to your torso. This will be your starting position. Now while keeping your upper arms stationary curl the weights up while contracting your biceps, focus on only moving your forearms. Continue to raise the weight until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the top contractive position for a moment and squeeze the biceps. Then inhale and slowly lower the bar back to the starting position before repeating.

Facing a high pulley with a rope or dual handle detached, pull the weight directly towards your face, separating your hands as you do so. Keep your upper arms parallel to the ground.

There are various implements that can be used for the farmer's walk. It can be performed with heavy dumbbells or short bars if other implements are not available. Begin by standing between the implements. After gripping the handles, lift the implements up by driving through your heels, keeping your back straight and your head up. Walk taking short quick steps and don't forget to breathe. Do for a given distance, typically 50 to 100 feet as fast as possible.

Hey, bodybuilding.com. I'm UFC Light Heavyweight and Monster Milk Athlete Ryan Bader. It's my coach Aaron Simpson. Today I'm going to take you through a three-part workout. The first one's going to be some dynamic stretching. Seconds going to be a agility ladder. And the third is going to be a strength circuit. You can use this workout as a warm-up. And I like to use it as I'm getting ready for a fight as a workout in itself. So let's dive right into the first section. From the first section, the stretching section we got six basically exercise we're going to do. The first one is knee hug and twist and basically you're going to bring your knee up, grabbing it with your hands, bringing to your chest, letting it down and going to be in a blunt position and then you can twist your body. Basically it's a whole body stretch. Instead of just doing static stretching we're doing active stretching. Next one we're going to go into is backward toe touches. We're doing the backwards lunge is stretching over and kind of pointing to the opposite direction. We're activating the lower back muscles. We're loosening up the muscles at the same time. We're strengthening the muscles also. The next exercise is going to drop lunge. You're going to keep that front foot front of you and you're going to drop that back leg kind of into those squat positions. We're going to go down one direction and back the other direction. The next one is backward toe touches. So basically you're going to kick your back leg out to the back while touching the front toe with your opposite hand and you're going to go back and bring it back doing the same exercise. You got to warm up your muscles, you got to warm up your core and get your body temperature up. The next one we're going to do the world's greatest stretch. One of my favorite ones we're going to do a lunge. We're going to bring our elbow down on the floor inside our leg and get a natural lunge stretch and then we're going to bring it back grab on our toe and get a little hamstring stretch from there and you're all to make legs. You can do these stretches anywhere. You just need a good little not-a-space. Once again I use it more as a warm-up but this can be used as an actual workout. I actually use it when I get closer to fights as a workout. The last one we're going to do do a little shoulder stretch. You can grab a bar, a little PVC pipe, whatever you got and you're going to basically bring it over your head, touch your butt, bring it back, do that 10 times and you pretty much take your whole body and it should be warm already to go. Going into the agility ladder, you can really mix and match what you want to do here. You'll go forward in each box so it's two feet in each box. It's kind of look like you're running. Obviously you start slow and as you work the way up you can get faster and faster. Next one we're going to go laterally so we're going to turn to the side and go two feet in each box, go down and back. That ladder doesn't matter how great a shape I'm going to be in perfect fight shape. That ladder gets my heart rate going and gets breathing a little heavy and as you do it and as you get better at it you're going to go faster so there's never really any end game barrier. You're going to get better. You're going to go faster. Next one we're going to do is hops. We're going to hop with two feet in each box and we're going to go down and back and backwards. We're going to get your body sweating, you're going to get your core warmed up, just to hold fast speed, the motion being able to concentrate and get your feet in there at the same time where they need to be. It just works well for me for being a fighter and it will work obviously on boxing and leetie and even on the ground so it's just good for everybody. The next one we're going to flip and go laterally and hop in and each each box two feet down and back. If you don't have an actual agility ladder you can actually make one out of tape or you can pretend there's one on the floor. It's better to have one because it will make you stay in the box and it kind of think about what you're doing a little bit but if you can do it on the floor, pretend there's one and you're still going to get the activation, you're still going to get the warm up and go about 20 feet or 20 boxes and you'll be good. The last one is called the achy shuffle. It's a little complicated to explain but you're replacing your feet in the box. If you're starting from the side you're going one foot in, one foot out, one foot in and then you're doing that down and backwards. The last one is a lateral achy shuffle so you're starting laterally. Same thing replacing your feet in the box going up and down through each box. The third part of the workout is more kind of getting into an actual workout but it's more body weight. You're activating your glutes, your legs, your hitting those big muscle groups and it's a great way to start anything as far as a workout or if you're training or anything like that. We're going to start with a single leg, blue bridge and you do this on any bench and you're going to lay down on the bench, spread your arms out, you're going to get on your heel, one leg's going to be up in the air, the other is one, one's going to be on the ground on your heel and you're basically dressing your hips up, activating your glute muscles and you're going to do 15 on one side and 15 on the other leg. Then we're going to go into wise and tees and this can be done with blast traps or it can be done with five pound weights on the incline bench. What it kind of sounds like is making a teet with your arms activating those shoulder muscles and then you're going to go into wise and you're going to do 10 of each. It doesn't matter if you're a professional MMA fighter, a bodybuilder or a person trying to get in shape, a good hard dynamic warm up like that. It's going to help your flexibility and it's also going to help your strength. The last exercise we're going to do hanging knee raises, have yourself a bar, hang from it, bring your knees all the way up to your chest as high as you can and do that 10 times and you're going to be doing two rounds of that circuit. To begin, first set the bar in a rack slightly below shoulder level. Rest the bar on the top of the deltoids, pushing into the clavicles and cross your arms while grasping the bar for control. Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time, straightening your torso. Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with your toes pointed slightly out. Keep your head and elbows up at all times. This will be your starting position. Now bend at the knees and set your hips as though you are sitting in a chair. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90 degrees. Keep your knees aligned with your feet by consciously using your abductors to push your knees out as you squat. Continue to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel or middle of your foot. As you straighten the legs again and return to the starting position.

This variation is a one to one ratio of a front squat right into a back squat with a belt. You're going to add your belt, pull it through, get it nice and tight. You're going to obviously be pushing in the belt with that thoracic pressure.
