So here we are at Gold Gym and I'm going to talk a little bit about my training techniques. I like to train heavy all year long. I focus my training schedule around the bench, the squats and the deadlift. All compound exercises to help keep that dense full muscle while you're training for a cover shoot. In past experiences I'd actually gone to more of a comfort team while training for photoshoot and I lost that dense full muscle that I wanted to achieve like I had for this previous shoot. I noticed that when I went to my photo shoots that I wasn't as hard and as full as I was previously when I was training with the heavier stellar training, I've gone back to that, like I said, I focused all of my workouts around the bench, the squat and the deadlift and dropped my rep range to four to six in the off season and then four weeks out from my shoot would raise the raise the rep range from eight to ten reps to really focus on sculpting and really getting that extra detail in the muscle. Two weeks ago with my last photo shoot I noticed that I brought back that full dense muscle that I wanted to achieve for previous shoots. So that's what I recommend is to train heavy but be consistent with that in train smart as well. It's easy to injure yourself in your training heavy so just be careful with the bench and squatting the deadlift, be smart about it, train hard, train heavy. Place the back of your torso against the back pad of the machine and hook your shoulders under the shoulder pads provided. Position your legs on the platform using a shoulder width medium stance with your toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up and back on the pad at all times. Place your hands on the side handles of the machine and disengage the safety bars. Then straighten your legs without locking the knees. This will be your starting position. Inhale and begin to slowly lower the weight down by bending at the knees. Maintain a straight posture with your head up and back on the pad at all times. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and calves is slightly less than 90 degrees. Now exhale and slowly raise the weight by pushing the floor with the heels of your feet as you straighten your legs and return to the starting position.

But I try and do usually as most weight, as I can do four 10 reps. Next set, most weight I can do for eight reps and so on and so forth. Think about the end goal that you want, picture it, you know, talk to other people, other people who have the same goals in mind, and that helps you, you know, save off those cravings. I know what supplements, you know, I used to think that supplements were the key. And like, I need to figure out what this person is taking. So, I don't know how he got so ripped. It's unbelievable. And then the other part is going to be, you know, the exercise supplements will help you achieve those goals, but they won't do all the work for you. Stand up with the dumbbell in each hand held at arms length. The elbow should be close to your torso with a palms of your hands facing your torso. This will be your starting position. Now what holding your upper arm stationary exhale and curl the weight forward while contracting the biceps. Continue to raise the weight into the biceps or fully contracted in the dumbbell as a shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a brief moment as you squeeze the biceps. Focus on keeping the elbow stationary and only moving your forearm. After a brief pause, inhale and slowly begin to lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Begin with a shoulder width, double overhand grip with the bar hanging at the mid thigh position. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward. Begin by aggressively extending through the hips, knees and ankles, driving the weight upward. As you do so, shrug your shoulders toward your ears. As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pole by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with your elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pole. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery. Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up, continue until you're up risen to a standing position.

Hanging from a chin up bar with both arms fully extended above you and either a wide or medium grip. Your legs should be straight down and your pelvis rolled slightly backwards. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and raise your legs until they form a 90 degree angle with your torso bending your knees as you do so. Hold this top contracted position for a brief moment, then inhale and slowly return to the starting position.

Hanging from a chin up bar with both arms fully extended above you with either a wide or medium grip. Your legs should be straight down and your pelvis rolled slightly backwards. This will be your starting position. Now exhale and raise your legs until they're at least perpendicular with your torso, bend your knees as you do so. Hold this top contracted position for a brief moment, then inhale and slowly return to the starting position.

Research is my passion. Muscle and strength are my pursuits. I'm the power lifter, bodybuilder, scientist and coach. I'm Lane Norton. I am a physique architect. I'm the power lifter. I'm the power lifter. Binge press is one of the most important upper body exercises. This makes it crucial for overall development and strength. A lot of people think about it as just a chess movement. But it incorporates the pectorals, the triceps, the shoulders, even the back when done correctly. When it's done wrong, the results can be disastrous. Seven years ago, I told my right pectoral, bench pressing incorrectly. But over time, I learned to incorporate more muscle groups and focus on the movement itself. Not only did it become more safe, but my results were better. In this video, I'm going to teach you things I learned from top technique experts like Ben Eskro, Dr. Mike Zordos and Matt Gary to make my bench press more effective, safe and fun. Before we actually get into talking about the nuts and bolts, I want to talk about something a lot of people don't really think about. That's equipment. Now you don't need any equipment other than yourself to bench press. But there are certain things that can make your bench press more effective and safe. Not many people give much thought to footwear on a bench press. But your feet are what connect you to the ground and form your base. Now footwear is a little bit of personal preference, but you want something with a lot of grip. Personally, I like to use squat shoes. They have an elevated heel, which helps me get my foot flat and the floor and connect with it better. They also have really good grip on the bottom, and that helps keep my feet from sliding. But many people also use wrestling shoes and shoes like Chuck Taylor's. Another piece that really isn't equipment, but I find to be very useful is Chuck. By putting Chuck on my back, it helps me stick to the bench better and form a more stable base to press from. The easiest way to apply Chuck is to use a partner or lifting buddy. Have them chalk your back where you're back contacts the bench. The most important piece of equipment I use on bench press is wrist wraps. If you're going to create the maximum amount of force, you want to be able to keep your wrist in a straight line. Briss traps give joint support helping you keep your wrist in a straight line. I recommend a good pair of powerlifting wrist straps anywhere from 12 to 36 inches, depending on what you prefer. Many people make the mistake of wrapping their wrists too low. You want the wrap to actually cover the joint. In fact, you want to wrap a little bit above and a little bit below the joint. This is why I prefer a bit longer wrist wrap of 18 to 24 inches. This ensures I can get enough revolutions to cover both above and below the wrist joint. Tightness is a little bit of a matter of personal preference. I say get them as tight as you can while not causing pain. Now that we've covered equipment, let's talk about what actually makes the components of a good bench press. The first thing I want to talk about is foot placement. While not as crucial as on squat or deadlift, it's still as important on bench press. It forms your connection to the ground and your base. I prefer to keep a flat foot on the ground. This ensures I get the best connection possible. I also like to keep my back tight and arched. To do that, I like to keep my feet back as far as I can while still keeping them flat. For everyone, this is going to be a different position. But you want to put them back, but not so far back that you can't keep them flat on the floor. The next thing I want to talk about is back position. As you lie down on the bench, you want to position your back in the appropriate position. For everyone, this may be a little bit different, but essentially what you want is to have your back in a position where you're not so far away from the bar that it becomes difficult to un-raq, but you're not so far under it that you're likely to hit the pegs when you're pressing. I prefer to put the bar right around forehead height, and this will put my back connection with the bench just below where the bar sits on the rack. So now that we're in the proper position, I want to talk about back arch. Now this tends to be a little bit of a controversial topic, especially among bodybuilders. Many bodybuilders don't think they should arch. They think that an arch is just a powerlifting move, but arching your lower back will help keep your spine neutral and protect it while you're pressing. But we'll also ensure your overall back can stay tighter. Now, if you're not concerned about powerlifting, maybe you don't need to arch as much as power lifters, but you should still keep a slight arch in your lower back. If you're a power lifter, then you want to arch as much as you possibly can to minimize the distance the bar has to travel. The next day I want to talk about is gripping the bar. You want to grab it tightly and with authority. This is going to activate your central nervous system and get you ready and cue you to stay tight. You want to put the bar as far down in your hand as you possibly can. If you hold the bar out in your fingers, it is more likely to cause your wrists to roll back. This means you are no longer pressing with optimal force. A straight wrist will be the most optimal way to press. So you want to hold the bar as low in your hands as you can. Grip width is going to be very individual depending on your arm length. People with longer arms will probably need to grip wider. People with shorter arms can grip more narrow. But I don't like exaggerated grips in either direction. Most people are going to be around the rings or just a few inches inside the rings. I also don't recommend a false or thumbless grip. While they may feel better, they are simply more dangerous. I've heard numerous stories of people dropping bars on their chest because they used a thumbless grip. Wrap your thumb around the bar and bench press more safely. The next day I want to talk about is squeezing your shoulder blades together. Squeezing your shoulder blades together will allow you to stay tighter. It also protects the shoulders. What I mean by squeezing your shoulder blades together is think about if you had a great shape in between your shoulder blades. You want to squeeze so tight that you crush that grip. Just like on squat, we want to breathe to create the maximum amount of interparison ill pressure, so we can brace more effectively and move more weight. Before you begin the movement, you want to take in a deep breath, unwrapped the bar, blow that breath out and take in another new deep breath before you start your first rep. Then you want to hold it and blow out forcefully as you lock out the weight. This will enable you to use more weight more effectively. One step that gets overlooked is unwrapping the bar. Just like on squat, we want to do this as efficiently as possible and not waste energy. The way I like to think about unwrapping the bar is not to lift the bar off the uprights, but I want to think about driving my back against the bench so hard that the bar just comes off. You want to take a deep breath, brace, drive your shoulder blades against the bench, and then slowly and in a controlled fashion pull the bar off the uprights. Now that we've gone through a proper setup on bench press, let's talk execution. After you've unwrapped the bar and you're ready to start your first rep, you want to take in a big breath and brace your abdominal wall just like you would on squat or deadlift. Once you're braised, initiate lowering the bar, think about trying to bend the bar into a u. This will enable the bar to lower naturally in a good position with your elbows tucked. By thinking about bending the bar, you're going to naturally engage your lats and tuck your elbows. We don't want to flare our elbows excessively on bench press. Tucking your elbows ensures that you'll engage your lats and press in a more safe and efficient manner. Another cue that may work is to protect your arm pits. Where you touch the bar on your body is very important and is going to be very different depending on how long your arms are and where you grip. One of the most important things for an efficient bench press is to keep your forearm at 90 degrees to the ground. If it moves in either direction, you're going to be losing energy transfer as you press up with the bar. Somebody who has long arms and grips narrow is going to have to touch very low on their body. If somebody has very short arms and very wide, they could touch very high and still keep their foremen at 90 degrees to the ground. But as we discussed, I don't recommend extreme grips in either direction. For most people, they're going to hit anywhere from their top ab to their nipple one. Once you've touched the bar to your chest, you want to initiate the upward movement by tightening your glutes and driving your legs in the ground. This may seem like a strange cue, but just like on squatting deadlift, using leg drive is going to enable you to use more weight and stay tighter. Now on bench press, because our feet are not directly under the bar, it's not as important as it is on squats and deadlift, but we're still trying to get every little bit of efficiency that we can out of our movement. As you start to press up, you want to think about throwing the bar back as you start the lock out process. Remember, we're pressing the bar in an upside down J path. Ideally, we'd have a completely straight bar path, but with most people on bench press, that's not going to be possible. If they do, the bar ends up too far away from you as you lock out and creates extra torque on your shoulders. Now that we've talked about how to do a proper bench press, let's talk about some of the most common mistakes I see when people do the movement. Probably the most common mistake I see is people bouncing the bar off their chest. Not only is this dangerous because the force you create on your sternum, but it's almost impossible to stay tight and controlled when you're bouncing the bar off your chest. And if you're bouncing it, are you really moving the weight? Another mistake is people don't breathe properly and brace properly. If you're not taking a big breath before you start and brace your abdominal wall correctly, it's going to be less safe and you're not going to be able to stay as tight and use as much weight. Another one of the most common mistakes I see is people flaring their elbows. Many people flare their elbows out because they believe this will lead to more chest recruitment. And even if it does, it's still not worth the danger. This was how I tore my pec seven years ago by using two out of a grip and flaring my elbows out. It also means you're not going to be able to keep your lats tight and it's going to lead to less efficiency in the movement. Another big mistake I see is rolling your shoulders forward. This tends to go hand in hand with flaring elbows out too wide. Many people tend to roll their shoulders forward as they finish the movement. But this is going to make you stay less tight and has a greater chance of leading to some sort of shoulder injury over the course of your lifting career. Another mistake that coincides with flaring elbows and rolling shoulders is unlocking your shoulder blades. Many people will unlock their shoulder blades as they finish a bench press because they feel it will enable them to lock out more weight. But that's not the case. It will cause you to lose tightness and increase the possibility of injury. Another mistake I see is people not keeping their feet planted. They have what I call floppy feet. It usually coincides with all the other cues we've talked about of not staying tight. Keep your feet planted to the floor. This will enable you to stay tighter and press more effectively. Now you have the tools to bench press effectively and safely. Remember lifting weights is a skill just like any other sport. And the more times you do it the better you will get at that skill. Start out with lightweight work on your form. Build it up over time. Now I know it's a lot to remember. There's a lot of cues when it comes to bench press. So go back and watch this video over and over until it makes more sense. You may pick up more things every time you watch. Also, I broken everything down in detail in this article at Bodybuilding.com. For more articles and videos from me and other great contributors, keep coming back to Bodybuilding.com.

Research is my passion. Muscle and strength are my pursuits. I'm the power lifter, bodybuilder, scientist, and coach. I'm Lane Norton. I am a physique architect. Just like with squats for the first half of my lifting career, I avoided deadlifts. It was hard, and I didn't really want to do it. But once I finally decided that I needed to catch my back up to the rest of my body, I consistently started incorporating deadlifts, and it made all the difference. When I did my first series of natural pro shows in 2010, the judges couldn't believe the difference I had made in back size and density. Now five years later, my back's gotten even bigger, and my deadlifts got even better. When I decided to consistently start deadliftsing, I did a ton of research on proper form and how to execute the lift. But I also learned from some of the best people I know, including Ben Eskro, Dr. Mike Zortos, and Matt Gary. Compiling all that information has led me to where I am today, and I'm going to use it to teach you how to deadlift or safely and efficiently. There are essentially two ways to deadlift. Either conventional or sumo. In this video, I'm going to break down both. Before we get into breaking down the deadlift, I want to talk about useful pieces of equipment I recommend for deadlift. Footwear is very important for deadlifts. You're looking for three things. One, you want something with a lot of grip, two, you want something with a flat hole, and three you want something that's loaded to the ground. Lower to the ground, you are the less distance you have to pull the bar. If you're using something with a raised heel, you have to pull the bar further. Thus, I don't recommend squat shoes for deadlifting. Also, I don't recommend sneakers. They're probably the worst things you can wear. You want something with a hard sole. Sneaker sole is very soft, and you'll be losing energy transfer when you deadlift. I recommend things like deadlift slippers, wrestling shoes, or even shock tailors. As with squat, a belt can be very helpful on deadlift. A belt gives you something to brace your abdominal wall against, and keep you more upright as you complete the movement. I recommend a good 10 to 13mm powerlifting belt. Most people wear their belt too though. I recommend wearing your belt just under your ribs, right where your abdominal wall pushes out when you brace during a lift. Belk tightness is a little bit up to the individual, but I don't prefer something so tight that you can't brace effectively, but you also don't want it so loose that it doesn't provide support. I recommend keeping it one notch off the absolute tightest setting that you can possibly go. As well as gusts later, a straight bar path is very important during deadlifts. It is also important to keep the bar as close as possible to your body. This means that if you're not wearing long socks or tights, you're going to scrape your shins. In fact, it may leave you bruised and bloodied. Thus, I recommend wearing either knee-high socks, tights, or long pants during your deadlifts. Another piece of equipment that you can use for is straps. Now, if grip is a problem for you on deadlift in your competitive powerlifter, I recommend training without straps. But if grip isn't a problem, or you're just a bodybuilder who's looking to maximize muscle mass and doesn't want to worry about your grip, then straps can be very helpful. If you're not going to use straps on a deadlift, I recommend using chalk. It will enable you to get a better grip on the bar, making it easier to complete the lift. So now that we've discussed equipment, let's talk about the components that make up a good deadlift. First, I'm going to teach you how to set up for a conventional deadlift. Foot position is a little bit up to the individual. But in general, I would stand in the position where you can generate the most power. And that is typically where you'd be able to jump the highest in a standing vertical leap. Your hand position should be just outside of your shins. If you grip too wide, you're actually going to have to pull the bar a further distance. So you want it as close to your shins as you can. After most starting position, we'll be with your shins at 90 degrees to the ground and your scapula over the bar. This ensures that you pull the bar in a straight line and generate maximum force. Just like on squat, before you begin the movement, you want to take in a deep breath and brace your abdominal wall. This is going to protect your spine and enable you to generate more force. Before you start the movement, you also want to pull the slack out of the bar by engaging your lats. Many people just jerk the bar off the ground, but this is incorrect. Jerking the bar off the ground is more likely to put whip into the bar and cause your lower back to round and prevent you from keeping a straight bar path. Now I'm going to show you how to set up for a sumo deadlift. Foot positioning on sumo deadlift is going to be more variable than on conventional, but you want to set up so that your shins end up at 90 degrees when you begin to pull. An easy way to find out where your foot position should be on sumo is to look into a mirror, get into your starting position and then play around with different foot widths. Find the one where your shin is at 90 degrees to start the movement. On a sumo deadlift, you're also going to need to point your toes out. If you point your toes forward, your knees are going to be in the way and it's going to be much harder to complete the movement. Your hand position should be a straight line down the bar. The rest of the setup points for sumo are very similar to conventional. You want your shins at 90 degrees to the ground, you want your scapula over the bar. You want to breathe and brace. You want to engage your lats and pull slack out of the bar. Now that we've talked about deadlift set up, let's get into the execution at the conventional and sumo deadlift. Many of the cues for the execution of the sumo and conventional deadlift are very similar, but we're going to start with conventional. As we discussed in setup, you want to breathe in deep, brace your abdominal wall, and pull the slack out of the bar by engaging your lats. Initiate the movement by thinking about trying to bend the bar. You want to breathe in deep, brace your abdominal wall, and pull the slack out of the bar by engaging your lats. Initiate the movement by thinking about trying to bend the bar. That will engage your lats automatically, and then pushing the floor away from you. Think about a leg press. It's similar to your setup on a conventional deadlift. You've got your thighs, close to your abdominal wall, and you're pressing the leg press away from you. So instead of the leg press, think about that being the ground. You're pressing the ground away from you. As soon as the bar leaves the floor, you want to think about squeezing your glutes and driving your hips forward. This is going to enable you to keep a straight bar path and lock out more effectively. You want to initiate the movement by thinking about spreading the floor apart. You want to initiate the movement by pushing the floor away from you. And as soon as you're deadlift, you want to initiate the movement by thinking about spreading the floor apart. Once the bar has left the ground, you want to think about squeezing your glutes and driving your hips forward, just like you would unconventional. As you lock out, stand erect, but do not hyper extend your lower back. Just stand straight up and lock out your lower back. Once you're locked out, you don't want to just drop the weight, but you don't want to lower it too slowly either. Many people I've seen injured their lower backs have done so trying to lower the bar too slowly. This creates a lot of torque on your lower back. The easiest way to initiate lowering the bar is to unlock your glutes and let your hips drive back. And the bar should be lowered in a straight bar path, almost identical to the one that came up in. One major point to note is that conventional and sumo deadlifts are not going to feel the same in terms of speed. A conventional deadlift is typically going to be very fast off the floor and slower to lock out. Now that we've talked about how to properly execute conventional and sumo deadlifts, let's talk about some of the most common mistakes we see in the gym. The biggest and most dangerous mistake I see on deadlifts is rounding of the lower back, spinal flexion. This creates uneven pressure on the disc and is more likely to lead to a back injury. Another big mistake I see is the bar separating from the shin. The further away from your body the bar gets, the longer the moment arm and the greater the torque on your lower back. Keeping the bar as close to your shin as possible ensures that you can apply the maximum amount of force and move the bar more effectively and safely. Another mistake I see people making is not engaging their lats and pulling the slack out of the bar. This increases the whip that goes into the bar, the likelihood that the bar will separate from your shin and increases the difficulty to lock out. Another mistake I see is people who lock their knees too early. While locking your knees earlier will help you get the bar off the ground faster, it will make it much more difficult to lock out because the bar will separate it from your shin, increasing the torque. Another really critical mistake I see people make is people who over-dip their hips trying to squat the right off the ground. The deadlift is not a squat. People who have long legs are not going to be able to get a lot of progress into the movement, especially on a conventional deadlift. Remember that in order to exert the maximum amount of force, the shin has to be perpendicular and the shoulder blades have to be over the bar. If you over-dip your hips and lean too far back, your shoulder blades will be behind the bar. To initiate the movement and for the bar to come off the ground, the shoulder blades will now have to get back over the bar. This means you will have to come forward as you start in the movement. Coming forward as you start in the movement is one of the worst things that can happen. If you're coming forward as you start the movement, you are much more likely to have the bar separate from your shin, lock your knees too early and round your lower back. While many people like to touch and go deadlifts, I do not. I see many people bouncing the bar off the floor, and with each rep they get less and less tight and get an awards and awards position. I recommend taking a split second to let the bar settle, make sure in a good position and restart the movement. As with any movement, the more you do it, the better you're going to get out of. I recommend starting light, focusing on bar path and the cues we discussed, and getting comfortable with the movement before you really start getting heavy. Remember, DevLift is a high reward movement, but it's also high risk if not done properly. Now I realize that's a lot of information across us at one time. That's why I recommend watching this video several times to pick up more and more tips. Along with this video, I recommend reading the detailed article here on bodybuilding.com. For more great articles and videos from me and other great contributors, keep coming back to bodybuilding.com.

Research is my passion. Muscle and strength are my pursuits. I'm a power lifter, bodybuilder, scientist, and coach. I'm Lane Norton. I am a physique architect. Swoy! I used to be that guy going to the gym with chicken legs. Why? Because I wouldn't squat. I made up every excuse you could think of as to why I shouldn't squat. They're bad for the knees, they're bad for the back, they're hard. Why didn't say that out loud, but I certainly thought it. So I used to every other exercise I could think of, and my legs were still tiny. One day I had to piffy me. I'm going to squat over 500 pounds for reps, and I will sue my will get big legs from that. After years and years of work, learning proper technique and programming, I did squat over 500 pounds for reps. With a top squat ever of 655 for a single, and my legs are no longer twigs I'm happy to say. Guys, if you want big legs, there's one rule. We got squat. In this video, I'm going to show you tips and techniques I've learned over the years from working with top coaches in the squat. To teach you how to squat, or safely, and effectively using big weights. Let's get into it. Before I actually get into teaching the squat, there's one aspect of squatting I'd like to talk about that often gets overlooked. And that's equipment. Now I'm about talking about a bar or a rack. I'm talking about things that you actually put on yourself. Now I would never tell you that you need equipment to squat. All you need is yourself. But I'm a big fan of things that I can put on, and immediately be better. Things that will make you squat more safely and efficiently. The first one is footwear. Most people wear tennis shoes, but unfortunately tennis shoes are one of the worst things you can use. The purpose of a tennis shoe is to distribute the load over your entire foot. And it's also the cushion you against impact. In a squat, you're pressing down against the earth, and physics dictate that the earth presses back up against you. If you have on a cushion shoe, you're going to lose some of that energy transfer. It's also going to make you on-stab. Many of you who squat sneakers probably notice that you feel like your knees cave in and you're wobbly. So at minimum, you want a hard-sold shoe. Now I am a huge fan of Olympic lifting squat shoes. The great thing about squat shoes is not only do they have a hard-sold, but they also have a slightly elevated heel. That puts you in a more ergonomic position for squatting and allows you to push off your heel and mid foot better. The next piece of equipment I like to talk about is a weight belt. I'm not talking about your weight belts that are flimsy and velcro. I'm talking about a buckled belt that's made of stiff leather. A good belt will give something for your abdominal cord of brace against. This will protect your lower back and keep you more upright during a squat. Now many people ask me, Lane, but if I wear a belt, my core will get less activation, and it will weaken my core. That's actually not true. The research shows that wearing a belt, if anything, increases core activation for two reasons. One, wearing a belt gives you something to actively push out against. And so your abdominal wall pushes against the harder. Two, you can use more weight and thus get more core activation. One other thing about wearing a belt is most people don't wear it properly. They wear it too low. It is not meant to go around your waist. It is meant to go around where your abdominal wall is going to push out during a squat. So I prefer to wear it a little bit higher than most people wear it. As for what kind of belt, I just recommend buying a belt from a reputable company that in either 10 or 13 millimeter that's 4 inches thick. Another piece of equipment we should talk about is knee sleeves and knee wraps. I personally prefer knee sleeves for a multitude of reasons. The biggest of which is that knee wraps simply take too long to get on and off. They'll slow you down during your workout and further. There is some evidence that placing that kind of pressure on the patella may not be optimal. Also, when I'm using weights, I like to know that I'm moving the weight. And I'm not getting a PR, just simply because I wrap my knees tighter. With knees sleeves, you get a consistent pressure each time that's repeatable and they're easy to get on and off. They still warm the knee joint and provide some level of protection. The next piece of equipment I recommend isn't really equipment, but it's still important nonetheless. Good shock. Now people might say, what the heck do you need chalk for? As we'll discuss coming up, bar position can make a huge difference. And in a low bar squat, chalk can help keep the bar on your back and keep it from rolling. So I recommend getting a good block of chalk and using that to help keep the bar in position on your back while you squat. The last piece of equipment I want to talk about is wrist wraps. For those of you who do high bar squats, wrist straps may not be necessary. But for those that prefer a lower bar position, wrist straps are extremely helpful. The wrist straps will help keep your wrist straighter and prevent elbow and wrist pain from squatting in a low bar position. One mistake people make with wrist straps is they use the wrap too low. They wrap below the wrist joint. You want to wrap above and below the wrist joint. This will provide more support for the wrist and keep it in a better position. One of the most overlooked aspects of a squat is the setup. I see so many people get into the bar and rush right into it. You should have a consistent pre-plan plan that you repeat every time you go to do a squat. You want to get yourself underneath the bar and in the proper bar position, whether it be low bar or high bar. You want your feet completely under the bar. Remember, your mid foot is your center of gravity. When you're ready to squat, take a large breath in, brace your abdominal wall and unwrap the bar. The easiest way to do this is to squeeze your glutes forward, and this will simply pop the bar right off the rack. I recommend against squatting the bar out of the rack. That is simply where you bend your knees and try to use your quads to take all the weight. Use your biggest and strongest muscle groups. Your hips, your lower back, your hamstrings, and your quads to unwrap the weight. Most of you out there are probably used to a high bar position. A high bar position with a bar sits on top of the trapezius muscles. A low bar position is where the bar sits about two inches lower on top of your rear delts. So what are the advantages and disadvantages to each? The squat usually makes it easier to stay in a little bit more upright stance for some people. It also is a more comfortable position. A low bar position is a bit more uncomfortable because your shoulders are budged up. But one advantage to the low bar position is that around 95% of people are going to be more powerful in this position, and able to use more weight. Now they will start out with a little bit more forward lean, but when they get to the lower part of the squat, they'll be able to keep more spine neutrality than people who use a high bar position. So why is it easier to keep better spine neutrality with a low bar position? Because the bar is further away from your pivot point, your hips. There is more torque on your lower back when you hit the bottom of a squat. By using a low bar position, this reduces the amount of torque on your lower back. So how do you know which one is better for you? I recommend trying both. But in general, people with shorter legs and longer torso are going to be more able to use a high bar squat position. Whereas people who have longer legs and shorter torso are probably better off with a low bar position. As this will reduce the amount of torque on the lower back when they lean forward. So how do you find where to put the bar during a low bar squat? Grab the bar relatively narrow, as narrow as you comfortably can. Put it on top of your traps where you usually keep it. Then simply slide it to the next shelf down. You'll feel the bar catch and that is your low bar position. Now that you're on rack the bar, you're ready to walk out. I like the three step walk out. It's efficient, simple and repeatable. Once you've unwrapped the weight, let it settle. Don't immediately start trying to walk backwards. But when you're ready, take a small step with one of your feet backwards. Once that foot is set and settled, then take another small step backwards with your other foot. That second step actually plants your first foot. Then with your other foot that you took the first step with. Take a small step back to line it up with your second step. Once your feet are in position, you can adjust your stance with slightly. Again, I don't recommend a super wide or super narrow stance. I recommend a stance that you would be in if you were going to do a standing jump. The last thing I want to talk about is toe point position. You don't want to exaggerate it of a toe point. If you're anywhere near 45 degrees, it's too much. But an easy way to find out where you probably should be. Once you're in your squat stance, squeeze your glutes and your feet will rotate naturally. Wherever they wind up, that's probably your optimal position for your toe point. Now you're ready to squat. The first and possibly the most important aspect of squatting is simply breathing. Most people don't take in near enough air. To the first thing you want to do, watch your in position is taking a deep breath as much air as you can get. If you do not breathe deep enough, you cannot brace as hard. And thus makes it more difficult to maintain spine neutrality during a heavy squat. Now many of you have been told. Breathe in on the way down on an exercise and breathe out on the way up. It's completely wrong. You can generate your most force when you're holding your breath. Now what do I mean by bracing? I'm not talking about flexing your abs. I'm talking about once you pull your air in, push out your abdominal wall as much as you possibly can. If I was going to throw a punch and hit you in the stomach, what would you do to prepare for that? You would brace. You want to do the same thing when you squat. Many people just say, just arch your lower back. But that's the wrong cue when you squat. Your abdominal wall is what stabilizes your lower back. Yes, you want your lower back neutral. But just simply arching will not be sufficient to keep it neutral. You want to make sure you're bracing. Taking in a deep breath and pushing out your abdominal wall as hard as you can. But not only protect your lower back, but it will also help keep you more upright in the squat. Most people think about the squat simply an up and down movement. But it's not. It's also back and forth. You want to start the squat with your hips. You want to start by driving your hips back and sitting down between your legs. This is the best cue I can give you. By using your hips and glutes, you're recruiting your biggest, most powerful muscle groups and joints. Once you've achieved depth, if you're braced correctly, you should start to come up on your own without even having to think about pressing. But as you start coming up, don't think about simply just pushing up. Think about also driving your hips forward and squeezing your glutes as you walk out. Even if you're halfway up in the squat, you can lock it out simply by driving your hips forward and not even having to think about driving up anymore. Now let me talk about what's in the hips and glutes. What do we do with our knees? As we begin to sit down between our legs and drive our hips back, we also want to drive our knees out slightly. You want to make sure that you're driving your knees out over where your toes point. So as your feet are pointed forward, your knees should mostly track in that same line. If they're pointed out, you should push your knees out slightly, tracking them in the same line as your feet. One of the things you don't want to do is have your knees shoot forward however. One of two things typically happens when you lead with your knees in the squat. One, because you're pushing your knees out further, your calves tighten and it causes you to have to fold forward in order to achieve depth. This increases the likelihood of spine flexion much more. The second thing that happens is because their calves get tight, people sense this, and they stop well short of parallel. In order to maximize gains and strengthen hypertrophy, you want to take yourself through a good range of motion. By keeping a more upright shin angle, this is going to help save your knees and put less torque on them. We talked about squeezing our glutes forward. One benefit of this is this pull your glutes into alignment with your spine, and also pulls the bar completely into alignment with your body. Now your lower back isn't just supporting the bar. Your entire skeletal structure is. As you finish the movement, lock your glutes out so that pulls the bar back into alignment again. The last part of the squat execution is talking about back angles. As I alluded to earlier, back angles are going to be very individual. One of the things I hear a lot is people telling other people that they should squat more upright. And while it's true, you should squat as upright as you reasonably can. That is going to be different for every person depending upon their structure. For somebody who has long femurs and a short torso, they're going to need significantly more forward lean to achieve depth and keep the bar over their mid foot. For somebody who has shorter femurs, they may be able to squat very upright with very minimal forward lean. The most important part, regardless of how much you lean forward, is making sure you maintain spine neutrality. I've talked a lot about this term. But let's discuss it briefly. Spine neutrality essentially means that your back is straight. Even if you're leaning forward slightly, your back is straight. What you don't want to have happen is go into flexion. Flexion is where you lose the neutrality in your spine and you cave forward. That is dangerous because it places uneven pressure on the discs in your back. Now we're going to get into actually what makes a good squat. The number one thing is making sure you get deep enough. Proper depth means your hip joint will go slightly below your knee joint. I think you should squat as deep as you safely can. For some people with longer limbs, they're not going to be able to go all the way down without losing neutrality in their spine. In that case, they should stop before they get to that point. But almost everybody can learn to do a good parallel or below squat. The next thing we're going to talk about is bar path. The bar path is the path the bar takes as you travel down and up during the squat. The proper bar path is going to start with the bar directly above your mid foot. And it should stay as close to the center of your mid foot as possible throughout the entire movement. That way the bar is directly over your center of gravity and you get the maximum force transmission from your feet to the bar. Now even with a really good squat, you may not have a completely straight line. But the fewer deviations from straight you have, the more efficient the squat is going to be and the easier it's going to be. This brings me to another point. I hear a lot of people say never lean forward on a squat. And while it's true, you should keep your back angle as upright as possible. This is going to be different for every person. If you have long legs, in order to keep the bar over your center of gravity and achieve proper depth, you must lean forward. Now you want to minimize that amount of forward lean, but you're going to have to have some. Leaning forward and of itself is not inherently dangerous. The key is to make sure you always maintain spine neutrality. In this video, I've given you the tools you need to squat heavy, safely and efficiently. But don't be surprised if you're not perfect the first time. In fact, I promise you you won't be. I'm learning and re-learning every single time. Remember practice makes perfect. Many of us don't think about lifting as a skill, but it's a skill. And the more frequently you practice it, the better you will get. So even if you're not training heavy, it can still be useful to go in, put lightweight on the bar, and just do the movement. Don't neglect your warm-upsets. It's not just for you getting warm, it's also practice. The more times you do it, the better it will be ingrained in your motor pattern. Remember, if you treat lightweight like a heavy one day, you will treat heavyweight like it's light. If you have any questions about this video or anything I've discussed, please feel free to find me on body space and on my website. For more great videos and articles like this from me and other experts, make sure to keep coming back to bodybuilding.com. Thank you.

My name is Lane Norton, I have a BS and biochemistry and a Ph.D. in nutritional sciences. I'm a competitive pro-natural bodybuilder and powerlifter. In this video I'm going to teach you about the One Rep Max. Why it's important for you? Why it's useful to know it and how to actually test it. So what is the One Rep Max? The One Rep Max is defined as the amount of weight that you can lift for one rep on any given lift. Many people think that the One Rep Max is only useful for powerlifters. And while it's much more important for them, it's still useful to know your ultimate strength as a bodybuilder from time to time. The One Rep Max is important to know because not only is it the ultimate measure of strength, but it can also help you properly build out your training block. For example, if I'm going to do hypertrophy specific work, staying at about three sets of 10 reps, I know that I should be training about 75% of my One Rep Max. This will allow me to complete the reps in sets and set up an appropriate amount of specific weight for that exercise. If I didn't know my One Rep Max, I might have to go by feel and perhaps I set the weight too high and fail or too low and it's too easy. By knowing your One Rep Max, you can objectively set up these training programs. Now technically, you can test your One Rep Max on any movement. But I think it's most useful for compound movements. So now that you understand why it's useful to know your One Rep Max, we're going to talk about how to actually test for it based on your experience level. Here's the protocol I recommend for people who have less experience testing their One Rep Max. What I want you to do is use the Bodybuilding.com One Rep Max calculator on this page. For whatever exercise you want to find out your One Rep Max, take a weight and a number of reps that you know you can do. Plug that into the calculator and that will give you an estimated One Rep Max. It will also provide you with various percentages of that One Rep Max so you can use it in the future to build out programs. Once you've entered that end, take 90% of that estimated One Rep Max and we're going to use this to test. So I want you to go into the gym, do the One Up that we're going to discuss later in this video, and then take 90% of that One Rep Max and do it for as many reps as you can. Now take that number of reps you get, go back to the Bodybuilding.com calculator and re-figure your One Rep Max. Using the 90% for reps is going to give you a much more accurate representation of your estimated One Rep Max. So now I'm going to break down how to test for lifters who have more experience with One Rep Max. Once you're stretching the mobility worker done, I recommend warming up on a lift in the following way. To actually test, you're going to be doing 6 One Up sets and then 3 attempts. On the first set, you're going to do 30% of your calculated One Rep Max for 8 reps. Then 40% for 6 reps, 50% for 4 reps, 60% for 2 reps, 70% for a single and 80% for a single. Once you've done your 80% for a single, you're ready to begin your attempts. I recommend resting between each One Up set as long as you need to be mentally and physically prepared for the next set. If you're feeling still following up and thinking you need an extra One Up set or 2, that's fine. But don't go overboard. You don't want to wear yourself out by the time you actually get to testing. On the flip side, you don't want to do 2 few Warmups. If you do the appropriate amount of sets, it's not going to wear you out. It's just going to ready your body for your Ultimate One Rep Max. For One Rep Max testing, I recommend your first attempt to be approximately 90% to 94% of your current or estimated One Rep Max. If you last warm up felt really easy, I would go to the higher side of that range. If you last warm up felt heavier, then I would go to the lower side of that range. For your second attempt, I recommend anywhere from 96% to 100% of your current or estimated One Rep Max. If you're first attempt felt really heavy, I would go more towards the lower end of that range. If it felt really light, I would go towards the higher end of that range. For your final attempt, I recommend 100% to 104% of your current or estimated One Rep Max. If you're second attempt felt really heavy, go towards the lower end. If it felt really light, go towards the higher end. Because you're using as heavy away as possible, testing your One Rep Max can be dangerous, so I recommend using a good spotter. I also recommend using as good a form as you possibly can. If you squat high, you bounce the bar for your chest on bench press so you hit your dead lifts. You're going to get a higher number than you should. Thus, the weights are going to be too heavy when you go into your program and you're going to miss weights and it's not going to be effective. How often you retest is really going to depend on your goals. If you're a power lifter and somebody who's strengths specific, you're probably going to test it a little bit more often than you would if you're a bodybuilder. If you're a bodybuilder, maybe you're looking at every 3-6 to even 12 months because it's not specific to your goals. But it's useful to have to build out your training blocks. If you're looking to bring you a training to the next level and utilize your One Rep Max, I recommend checking out my PH3 trainer here on Bodybuilding.com. In 13 weeks, you'll increase strength and muscle mass significantly. For more free videos and articles from me and other great contributors, keep coming back to Bodybuilding.com.

So I want to talk about one of the impact caffeine can have on your sleep if you're having it closer to bed time. And then too, how to really understand what that sweet spot is for you. Yeah, caffeine is tough because there are a lot of positive studies about caffeine. There's a lot of positive performance studies. There's cognitive studies. There's long-term brain health studies, all positive stuff for the most part, but when it comes to sleep, it can have a big impact, as we know. And I think that just being intentional with caffeine is the biggest thing. So the first thing is with caffeine is I like to treat it like a play action pass in football, which obviously plays football. So I relate everything to that. But a play action pass, if you want to play action pass every play, it's not going to work. You have to mix it in. You can only run it every so often and it works really well because you take, you kind of catch a deep into off guard. Well, caffeine is the same way. If you don't use it for a couple of days, you have a big workout, a big event, a big meeting, a big presentation, and then you use it, it's really impactful. It works really well. When you use every single day, the exact same dose, over and over again, even after a couple of weeks, you're not going to feel that. So I recommend people just to save it for when you need it. It'll have a much larger impact. And you're probably going to enjoy it more because it works. It's like anything. If you do it too much, it's just going to become routine and it's just a habitual at that point. How does that consumption timing impact sleep as well? So the half-life of caffeine is pretty long. It's between five and six hours. Everybody is different. Some people are extremely sensitive to caffeine. They're genetic tests and you can actually see if you're one of those people. For the most part, the earlier you can have caffeine, the better, because it tapers off over a long, long period. And when you have multiple doses, they stack on each other. We metabolize it relatively slow. So even 200 milligrams of caffeine in a day, which is a pretty average amount. If you have 108 AM and then 100 at noon, that's going to linger in your system much longer because your body is not able to metabolism or metabolize it upfront, kind of stacks on top of each other and then it's going to stay with you throughout the night. So really front loading it is the most important thing. And the other thing that makes more sense physiologically because caffeine prevents us from feeling tired, more than even gives us energy. It blocks the adenosine receptors which basically makes this feel tired throughout the day. So when you think about when you're having it, you want to feel tired later in the day. Unless there's something specific. Like unless you do have a big event competition in the afternoon, yes, you would use it then. That's a perfect way to use it because it's going to block the thing that is making feel tired. As far as how we usually function in the way most people's days are set up, it makes more sense to have it earlier in the day and kind of prevents you from feeling tired throughout the day and tapers off for the night. Because for example, if someone has like three cups of coffee, 100 milligrams cup of coffee, which is small. Not many people will have 100 milligrams cup of coffee. But if they have an like 8, 11 and 1 PM, which is pretty standard, I don't think anybody would be like, oh, that's crazy. But even with that, you'll have around 80 milligrams of caffeine in your system at 11 PM, which a red bull has 80 milligrams of caffeine. So it really stays with you. So I think in tensionality and making sure you need it. Experience a couple of days without it. And really think about, do I feel a difference? Because oftentimes, two people have large doses of caffeine. They feel more anxiety. They feel more edgy. They feel like they're more irritable. And some people feel significantly better. Electroacupuncture medicine blends the classical channel theory of acupuncture with modern research to regulate the nervous and immune systems utilizing both treatment approaches have provided the best clinical outcomes for a wider variety of patients. Hey guys, Hunter LeBraude here. Today I'm going to be taking you through a brutally quick 3 exercise calf workout. It's going to be high rep, quick pace, and aim that maximum high hypertrophy. We're going to start with standing calf raises. From there we're going to move on to seated calf raises. Finally, to finish it up, we're going to move on to one leg at the leg press calf raises. So the first exercise we're going to be performing today is a standing calf raise. We're going to be forwarding five sets of 30 repetitions with the last two sets being a triple drop set. The reason we're going to be doing slightly higher reps to start out for this workout is your calf muscles unlike any other muscle in your body and that all day long every step you take you're using your calf. So it takes significantly more stimulation and significantly more reps to train than any other muscle that I've found in my experience. Your calf is actually made up of a couple different muscles. You have the gastric nemesh which is the muscle but most people assume is the calf muscle and then you have what's called the solius. The gastric nemesh is best trained with your leg, joint, lock down your leg, joint being your knee, lock down. You can assure that you lock this joint up by contracting both your quads and your glutes when performing your standing calf raises. What this is going to do is just going to isolate the gastric nemesh, take the solius out of the equation and make your body very rigid, taking away the injuries you might sustain to your lower back. You might also notice that in the video I was wearing a belt that's just another step in precaution to take and keeping your lower back nice and firm and straight. When performing these triple drop sets it's imperative that you keep the time that you take to drop the weight in between the sets as minimal as possible. Ideally you'll have a training partner there to strip the weight for you or be using a pin selectorized machine where it takes very, very short amount of time to drop the weight. Worst comes to worse and you have to make do and do it like I did on a standing Smith just bust it, I can get around there and take the plates off and get right back out and they're in good after it. But you want to keep the rest periods down and you don't want to take time in between them to recover. The last two sets of the triple drop sets serve to be able to keep the weight high because you want to keep the weight high enough to be stressing the muscle and breaking down the muscle fibers. But you're unable to perform a set all the way through with heavy enough weight to do that. So the last two sets being the triple drop sets you'll hit 10 reps at a weight that you can barely hit 10 reps at drop but again to a weight you can barely hit 10 reps at and finally finish up with a weight you can get another 10. It should not be comfortable it should not be enjoyable it will hurt but it will give you results. Moving on to the seated calf raises the reason we perform the seated calf raises is to train the solace the solace is activated whenever your knee is at a bent angle. So unlike the standing calf raises where we're going out of the way to make sure the knee joint is locked as possible. When we do the seated calf raise you're going to want to have an angle in the knee. Obviously you're going to be seated doing it. Something to keep in mind when doing your seated calf raises is you don't want to hyper extend your Achilles at the bottom. Once you get past a certain point all of the tensions taken off the solace in place entirely on your Achilles you can kind of see this indicated by whenever you're at the bottom of your rep whenever your feet start rolling in that's kind of transitioning from the solace to the Achilles tendon. So there's no purpose and muscle growth and it causes a lot of undue stress on the tendon. Another thing to keep in mind when training your calves is that it's really important to you to good contraction at the top. You'll notice that when I'm performing these workouts I almost perform a double clutching riff at the top. I'll get as high as I can normally. I'll let it sit there for a second and then I'll really force it to contract and I might only get an inch higher when I do that but it's really forcing a full contraction out of the muscle. Doing that like any other exercise and using any other machine it allows you to use a little less weight while placing additional stress on the muscle which is what we're after. It's imperative that throughout the work you keep the rest period under 60 seconds, optimally being around 45 seconds. If you're training with someone it should be as long as it takes them to do their set and then it's NASPAR PIPCruestyle to get on there get your weight set and for you to do your set. Moving on from there we're going to finish up with one leg head like press calf phrase. The reason we do it one leg head is you know throughout the work that you might get more and more fatigued on one side of the other so it's just one good way to ensure at the end of the work at the you really are able to thump both sides equally. In addition to that when you perform the seated leg press calf phrase is your neither straight nor bent with your knee there's a very slight angle in it so you've already attacked the gastric knee and is by doing it standing you've attacked the solius by doing it seated so the finish here is going to be the leg press one leg head calf for because you're isolating each side and you're isolating both muscles there are already worn down so it's a great finish for any calf work out in one that I really enjoy. A question I could ask often is how often to train your calves. Any calf work out including this one I believe can be used up to two times a week if you're truly training the calves to failure they will be sore for two to three days after you train them. That being said I do believe it is a muscle that requires more than a once a week training split because of how often the muscle gets used throughout the day and throughout the week is I previously stated you do have to go above and beyond to really get growth out of them. It's a lot of work and it hurts but my calves have grown tremendously and I brought them up from a week point to a strong point by doing so so don't be scared of training your calves more than once a week you will re-thru awards. To implement this work I'd enter your split I have two different recommendations. If you want to include it on your leg day I really strongly recommend you start with your calves. By starting with your calves and doing this workout you might not have as much energy to train your legs so it's definitely going to be a prioritization of calves if you employ it that way. If you aren't looking to diminish the performance of your calves and hamstrings due to the fact that you're missing energy because of how hard this workout is I would definitely recommend using an antone stand alone day or tacking it on to a workout that doesn't involve your lower half such as shoulders, back or chest. With your body straight, cross your arms in front of you. You can hold a weight plate for extra resistance if needed. This will be your starting position. Now start bending forward slowly at the hips as far as you can while keeping your back flat. Moving forward until you feel a nice stretch on the hamstrings and you can no longer keep going without rounding your back. Then slowly raise your torso back to the starting position.

The myths behind women lifting heavy is the craziest part about all of this for me. One of the things that happens to me multiple times a day. Women walk up to me and say, you look amazing, how did you get like that? Not a single woman on this planet, naturally, is going to look like a man if she lifts heavy. We simply do not possess the levels of testosterone and our body naturally to get that way. No squads are going to turn you into a man in the gym, but they're certainly going to give you a nice butt. I don't think that women eat enough. I eat 2,400 calories a day sometimes. Sometimes that's a thousand calories more than they're currently eating. So what I usually advise is to figure out their basometabolic rate, and there's plenty of calculators on bodybuilding.com to figure that out, you can always research it and look it up, and you can kind of find out what your maintenance calorie level is. If you're losing weight from that maintenance amount, that means that you can probably bump it up a little bit if your goal isn't to lose weight, you need to make sure that if you're lifting heavy, you're feeding your body enough. So add a few hundred calories. You are not going to change your body if you are under eating and not getting enough calories. No changes happen to the body if you're eating a thousand calories a day. A lot of women don't know exactly what to do when they are trying to lift heavy. Does that mean bicep curls? Does that mean cav raises? Does that mean lunges? The biggest bang for your back and lifting heavy is called compound lifts. compound exercises are things that recruit other muscle groups. So think about squats. If you're squatting, you're working on your balance, you're working on your core, you're holding a bar on top of your shoulders, you're working quads, glutes, hamstrings, calves, so many things. So think about the amount of different muscles that are working when you do one exercise. When you lift heavy, your body is breaking down muscle. So the magic really happens after your session in the gym. Your body is requiring extra oxygen to repair the muscles which burns extra calories which increases your metabolism. And all of that's happening after your workout while you're sitting at home, channel surfing. You're burning all those extra calories. You can do all the cardio you want. You can watch any insanity DVD you want and burn a thousand calories in an hour. But none of that after burn effect happens after cardio workouts. It all happens after you lift weights. Life flat on the floor on your back with your arms extended straight back behind your head. This will be your starting position. As you exhale, bend at the waist while simultaneously raising your legs and arms to meet in a jackknife position. The legs should be extended and lifted at approximately a 45 degree angle from the floor and the arms should be extended and parallel to your legs. The upper torso should be off the floor. While inhaling, lower your arms and legs back to the starting position.

Hi, I'm Jamie Eason and today I'm in the bodybuilding.com kitchen to show you how I make my 3-been chili. It's a one-pot dish super easy to make and it comes together fairly quickly. I've already started and in this large pot I've added some onions, diced onions, I did about a whole cut but the recipe calls for a half cut by just really like onions and then I did two pounds of extra lean turkey and about a tablespoon of garlic. I've already browned it, I drained off any excess fat and I'm ready to add the rest of my ingredients. To the turkey I'm going to add some diced green chilies. These come in a can and I chose two four ounce cans. You can use one if you'd like but I actually like the flavor of these are just only slightly spicy. They've got hot and they've got mild. I chose mild. I'm going to add those in. Give it a little stir in between. And then we'll add the beans. Now I call it my tribean or my 3-been chili because there's three different types of beans. There's an organic can-been that comes with pinto, kidney and black beans and you'll notice on the cans if you buy the organic version. Really it's nothing more than just beans and salt. Hey everyone, it's Jamie's and here welcome to Special Installments on Tips and Techniques that can help you achieve your fitness goals. My 12-week trainer consists of three four-week phases and I really want you to follow them to the letter the way they were designed to be followed. Following your instincts in the gym, it's a great thing but only after you've learned to be dedicated and consistent by following a program like this one for three months. Be consistent now and you can be creative later. Let's run through a few tips and techniques that didn't fit into the three phases. They'll help you stay the course and achieve even better results when you otherwise will achieve. My first tip is to keep a training journal. You can write down your sets, reps, and weights allowing you to track and review your progress. Hopefully you'll see strengthened creases and endurance gains as well as sticking points that may need addressing. You can even track factors like how you felt during a certain workout, what exercises or machines you got the most from, and what progressions you like the best. Down the road, when you might be feeling less than inspired or motivated, referring back to your training journal can provide motivation and a no-brainer way to get back into the swing of things. By keeping a journal, you'll also hold yourself accountable. It's easy to become complacent with a routine. Seeing it on paper will remind you to keep pushing for progress and challenging the muscles in a new way. Another great tip is to find a committed training partner. Having a fitness partner can help create accountability and keep your workouts on track. Also an extra boost of friendly competition during the workout can actually serve as a great motivation and bring more energy to your lifts. You'll be amazed at how much more weight you can push around when someone else is tearing you on or talking trash. Another tip to stay motivated with your workouts is to visualize. Start with visualizing the body you want to have some day. Don't hesitate to look for pictures of people who's a physique you admire, cut them out of magazines, maybe print them from the internet. By having a constant reminder of what you want to achieve, you'll stay motivated. If that athlete can build a physique you desire, then so can you. Another helpful technique is to visualize the exercise in your workout before you start. Take a minute or so and run through the movement in your mind. If you're unclear about your fitness goals, you'll lack the drive to reach them. Visualizing is a great way to get excited about the workout ahead and keep your energy level high. One of the common frustrations for fitness-minded people is hitting a plateau. You're cruising along, making progress, and the next thing you know, you're stuck, seemingly without reason. Maybe you're no longer getting stronger, maybe your endurance is lagging, maybe you've stopped shedding pounds. Either way, you're still doing what you thought you were supposed to do only it's not working like it did before. My 12-week trainer is designed specifically to avoid platoes. But after the program ends and you continue training, they could become an issue. The best way to rise above a plateau is to add variety to your routine. I'd recommend changing things up once a month, hopefully to avoid them. That doesn't mean you have to alter everything in your workout from the ground up. It just means trying some different combinations of sets, reps, and rest time or maybe changing around the workout split. For example, one change would be if you've been doing the standard three sets of 10 reps, try going heavier for fewer reps. Then there's the rest periods in between the sets, which many people forget to ever change. Something you could try is resting for two minutes on your heavy days, and only 30 seconds to a minute on your lighter days. You might be surprised at the difference this makes. Oftentimes we lose track of just how long we're resting. If you have a hard time keeping track of time with the gym, just grab a stopwatch to take with you or download the gym boss application on your phone. If you've already tried different reps, sets, and rest period schemes, another option might be trying different body parts splits. For example, you could do an upper and lower body split. So on Monday, you train chest, shoulders, biceps, triceps, and back, and after an active rest day on Tuesday, on Wednesday you'd only train legs, but maybe some abdominal work thrown in for good measure. There's literally hundreds of workout combinations, exercises, and splits that you can do. You may have to plan and research a little bit, but with a huge resource like bodybuilding.com's exercise in article database, there's not a lot of room for excuses. You can definitely find a way to change up your routine and rise above any plateau. Training may not be the only reason you're stuck in a plateau. If you've hit a weight loss plateau, it could have something to do with your nutrition choices. And there's a few things you can do to kick start your progress here as well. One thing I suggest is riding your meals down in a food journal similar to the training journal. A food journal is a great way to hold yourself accountable and track what you're putting into your body. You may start to see patterns in your diet you weren't even aware of. A food journal can also become a history of your successes and unfolds. If you start to see really great results from your diet, you'll have a record of what worked for you and you can always refer back to it. After you lock into a routine of working out, eating healthfully, and challenging yourself, you may think it's okay to skip your postwork out shake because you aren't really trying to change your physique anymore. Don't make that mistake. Just consider your postwork out shake or meal as essential. It'll help your body recover fast and move your closer to your goals. I'm also including some homework out options for both upper and lower body. These aren't really alternatives. They're great glass in case of emergency solutions just if you simply can't get to the gym that day like if you're traveling. I hope these tips are helpful and will keep you on track. The more tips like these, be sure to log on to bodybuilding.com and check out our monthly features. Curiotically, we provide incentives and new ideas to help you stay motivated and you'll find professionals like myself ready to support you in reaching your goals.

During today's workout, we are training chest, and the goal of today's workout is to build some mass and strength simultaneously. The benefits from this workout is to really get your body used to working under a heavy weight load and experience a lower reps so that you can really tear up the muscle, get the blood pump in there, and really build some serious mass to your chest area. This workout consists of six different exercises, four compound movements, and two isolation exercises to finish off your chest workout. This workout should take no longer than 60 minutes with no longer than a minute to two minutes in between each set. This first exercise is the machine fly. It's basically to warm up your pectoral muscles, to really get into some heavy movements later on in the workout. The consists of three sets of 15 reps from lightweight to medium weight, and you really want to concentrate on the stretch and the contraction at the beginning and the movement to really get the butt pump in in the pectoral muscles. With workout at the chest, I'm really big into warm up sets. I picked a machine fly movement to warm up, because it really isolates the pectoral muscles and really gets the butt pump in and gets my body ready to really lift some heavy weight. The first exercise is the barbell flat bench, and I'm using the pyramid method. Starting with four sets for ranging from a rep range from 10, 8, 6 and 4, and really on your last set. You really want to try to really push it from three to four reps. I always like to lay flat on the bench with an archer malor back, even my feet under me are really pushing through the heels, so you concentrate all on the power of pushing with your pectoral muscles. The flat bench pretty much is your meat potatoes for your pectoral muscles. It works your upper and lower chest and your shoulders and triceps at the same time. The second exercise is the barbell incline. I like to use this movement as my second exercise, because it's another compound movement. Really let you move some heavy weight and really tear up the muscle again, also as like the flat bench. I use here three sets and you want to get any range from 10 to 6 reps, really your first set. You really want to get around the 9 to 10 range and you last set, it really forced the reps out from anywhere from 5 to 6. During this exercise, you really are feeling fatigue, but you don't want to sacrifice form and do as much weight as your body in hand will. Alright, with the third exercise we're doing a dumbbell flat bench, again another compound movement and we're doing another press exercise because we're really concentrating on building mats and strengthening your chest and this is another exercise that really concentrates on working your upper and your middle of your chest. With the dumbbell flat bench, we are more concentrating now on using stabilizer muscles that we didn't get to use with the barbell incline and the barbell flat bench. This again is another movement that's going to help you really build some master strength to your chest. With the dumbbell flat bench, I really try to concentrate on really getting the stretch of the bottom of the movement and then really concentrate on stretching and contracting my chest at the top of the movement. That way you're getting the maximum blood flow to the chest area. With this exercise we're doing a superset and we're really concentrating on two isolation movements. We are starting with dumbbell flies and then we are moving straight into dips to failure. On this exercise we're really concentrating on doing four sets of six to ten reps. When you're actually performing the fly, you're really concentrating on getting a deep stretch at the bottom of the movement and then when I'm coming up I like to rotate my wrist in and that way we can track into chest and really get in the good squeeze at the top. On the dipset section of the superset, I really have the concentrate on keeping my body leaning forward. This keeps emphasis on the pector muscles. With this lack section of the workout, you really want to give it every last effort that you have.
