Hey, I'm Jesse Holgombard, NLA for her athlete, and I'm here to talk to you ladies today about why women should be lifting. I spend so much of my time coaching women on how to change their bodies, yes, on the outside their physique, but how to also change your lives and your bodies on the inside to reflect those lifestyle changes. Lifting has obviously changed my physique and my life in more ways than one, but I wanted to give you some key points on what I believe are the most important reasons for why you should be lifting too. Number one, reason why women should lift is it gives you confidence. I cannot stress this enough. I have so much more confidence now in my mid-30s than I have in my entire life. When I first started training, I would walk into a gym and I would really be frozen. If I wasn't training with my husband or a friend, I truly had no idea what to do. Even if I knew what machine to go to, I was so worried that people were watching me, and I wouldn't know how to adjust the machine or sitting on the machine wrong. All those things are running through my head, and I didn't have the confidence that I should have when you want to go into the gym and you want to have a great workout. So now that I've been lifting, I feel like I own the gym when I walk in, and I love that. It's taken some years as taken some experience, but if you just keep going to the gym, keep lifting, you build up your physique, you're going to build up that confidence and you're going to walk into the gym, you're going to take whatever equipment that you need to take, and you're just going to kill your reps in your sets, and you know what? So what if people are watching me? They're probably watching me, wanting tips for me, wanting to know how I'm doing, what I'm doing, and nothing feels better than that when you're in the gym with that kind of confidence. Outside of the gym, I can't even go grocery shopping in a tank top without women and men stopping me saying, Girl, you look so good, what do you do? What do you do? And it's just really neat to be able to say, I lift. It's as simple as that. I say, I go to the gym and I lift. It's just so neat to be able to put on a dress or put on an awesome pair of jeans or favorite jeans and just have those curves and feel good about your body and walk out there in the world and just know that you feel great and you look great. The second point I want to touch on is a really, really awesome one because we get to eat all the carbs we want. Well, maybe not all the carbs we want, but we get to eat a lot of carbs. If you're lifting with intensity in the gym, you get to eat, you have to eat. You won't have an intense workout if you're not properly fueled before you work out. A lot of women are really scared of carbs, is it gonna make me fat? Is it gonna make me gain weight? And it won't, as long as you are lifting with intensity and have consistency in the gym. You need those carbs to change your physique. So if you have carbs all day long on a leg day, for example, your body will use every drop of fat to grow muscle to maintain muscle and to completely change your physique. And that's a pretty darn good reason. It's gonna be a lot of women get fat. Another awesome tip is that the more muscle you have, the more calories you burn. It's as simple as that. So build more muscle and your body has to work harder and burn more calories to maintain that muscle mass than it does to maintain body fat. When we do cardio only for example, we are burning fat, but we're not really building muscle. But as soon as that session ends, the fat burning stops. When you lift weights with intensity, you are burning fat and you are burning calories. And the really awesome thing about lifting weights is as soon as that session is done, the fat burning does not stop. Your metabolism is increased. You're burning all day long. You go home and you're resting. You're still burning calories. Your metabolic rate has increased and you're going to have the effects of that training session all day long. And all night long while you're sleeping. So I don't know about you, but I'm really into burning fat while I sleep. The next point I want to discuss with you ladies is something that you may or may not be concerned about quite yet in your life. But as women we are at higher risk of osteoporosis. And what that means is we're at higher risk of fracting our bones, breaking bones. And the way we can absolutely squash that is by lifting weights with intensity. And I don't mean, you know, a few reps here and there on machines, a little bit of circuit training. I really mean intensity. Get into the gym. You can use machines. You can use cables. You can use dumbbells. You can get in the squat rack. Whatever is comfortable for you, just lift weights and whatever you're doing. You will build muscle mass. You will increase your bone density and you will increase your strength, which will help you later in life. It'll help you now, but it'll also help you later in life to reduce that risk of that osteoporosis, which you definitely want to avoid all of those bone fractures and breaks at all costs. The second technique we're going to talk about today are partial movements. The best way to demonstrate those are using the bench breast inside the Power Rack. Partials are all about overload and with partials you can overload the target muscle more than you can through a full range emotion. So remember, partials are angle specific. Meaning you only gain strength that they angle your working. So that's what's great about the Power Rack. They have so many different angles for you to work in that if you can gain strength at all those various angles, then you'll add up to one powerful strong full repetition. To demonstrate the partial we're going to utilize the bench breast. Let's get started. So now that you've set the bar and the weight is set and the bar is clipped. Go ahead and lie back. Make sure your back is fully supported. Your feet are flat on the floor. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, wrapping your thumbs around for safety. As you can see, I've set the angles pretty high towards just about six to eight inches from the top. The good thing about the Power Rack is you can change those angles whether it be in the same workout, lower in the angles or from week to week. Much like partials are angles specific. The Power Rack can help you be goal specific. So whether you're looking for strength, keeping your reps between one and six or perhaps high-perchriffe, muscle size, keeping your reps from eight to twelve or even endurance. Going as high as 25, the partial technique can be useful in supporting those goals. So just make sure that because you are stronger, let's say right here, I'm much stronger in this five to six inch range than I am in a four inch emotion. Be certain that you load the bar with enough weight that causes you to fail at your particular goal reps. So if my goal is ten repetitions and I'm doing it in a partial range, I better make sure that I fail at those ten reps. Don't put your standard 10 RM on a partial movement otherwise it can be too light. So make sure that wherever angle you are, it's also specific to the failure point of your target rep range. The good thing about using the power rack in this way, you can roll the bar back, right over head, which really incorporates the front delts, the middle delts, and the rear delts. You just much of the shoulder involved as possible to do as a bar is directly overhead. Remember, Parsons are all about overload. With Parsons, basically we're breaking the lift into smaller components within the range of motion, allowing you to handle a weight that's much heavier than you could normally use if you're working in a full range of motion. Remember your gains in strength will be limited to that particular range of motion that you train. And so make sure that you adjust the safety bars up and down, working various parts of the range of motion. So you gain strength throughout it.
